column9: **** Adderall helped me get through an intensive graduate school program by allowing me to focus on my reading assignments and projects after a long full day at work. It also elevated my mood. I felt happy that I was managing work and school well. I never abused the dosage and took it on a daily basis with the approval of my doctor for a year and a half until I suffered from a ruptured brain aneurysm. I never had high blood pressure and my EKG was fine before starting the medication. I did notice that my BP had gone up while on the medication but I just attributed that to the extra demands of grad school and a new teaching position. I was one of the Extremely lucky ones to survive the ruptured aneurysm w/o complications. My neurosurgeon said that the rupture could have been brought on by the use of this drug and demanded I immediately stop using it. Because of this I would not recommend it's use by anyone. I'm a teacher and would rather see kids or adults bouncing off the walls or daydreaming away then lying in a coffin.

column9: For the lady with is worried about her 29 year old daughters hair falling out.  I am 26 years old and have taken adderall since i was 13.  So pretty much everything that most of the things people are saying they are going through in these reviews, they have already come and gone with me.  But the last is the hair loss with me.  Right now Im going to a dermatologist just to figure out my massive hair loss problem.  I fear I will almost be bald by the end of the year (but mostly because my last dermy was a moron and never even ran tests). My suggestion is get her to a Dr.  Get a blood test or test the scalp tissues.  Thyriod/depression/stress/hormones are easily grouped and can be disguised.  And with this disorder is hard to figure if its just you or could actually be an underlining problem.  I have my other dermys apt tomorrow.  Ill respond when i have a better problem with whats going on with me because i can almost guarantee it might be the same thing.

column2: red, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Currently I am taking Adderall XR 20mg a day and have been doing for about two weeks now. Three months ago I was initially prescribed 15mg of the XR. I have a more inattentive form of AD/HD and I immediately noticed a difference in my ability to focus and concentrate, especially in school. However, as others have complained I notice it does seem to wear off a bit. It's possible I need a higher dosage for more effectiveness but I noticed I have begun jaw clenching and my dry mouth is insane! Although it's possible the dry mouth is from my Depakote. I have a Mixed Bipolar co-morbid AD/HD diagnosis. This medication is overall quite effective and can make a life changing improvement for some. However I want to caution this medication shouldn't make a person with true  AD/HD feel "tweaked out", sped up, or high. It should just elevate awareness, focus, and an overall attention to detail. That's why I agree that it is safe for kids truly suffering from this diagnosis should take a stimulant medication such as Adderall. You will notice immediately if these medications will be a right fit for you.

column9: I used Adderall to help me study in college. It is DEFINATELY effective. Though I didn't experience any ral negative side effects - other than being a little jittery and unable to sleep sometimes, I felt a little sketchy about continuing to use it when I graduated. It does show up at an amphetamine in drug tests, and I didn't want to tr to explain that in a job interview. Now I have been takng what they call Cognitive Energy Enhancers. They are over-the-counter and are basically a combination of a 5 Hour Energy and a brain vitamin. But they work! I have tired a few, but I like one called PROFIDERALL as an Adderall alternative. It is not as intense as Adderall, but it gives me the focus and energy boost I need to get my work done, and it is totally legal.

column2: footballdline, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Wow, thank you everyone for your imput.Special thanks to the Dr.for the honesty reguarding the addiction issues. I can relate to the person who said someone can talk to you for 10 minutes and you don't remember a thing they daid. I too use adderall for it's intended porpuse. Unfortunantly, I also use it and have abused it a lot.I moved 2,500 miles about 12 years ago just to get away from what was the meth Capital of our great country San Diego at that time. Thank God meth is not a major problem in Western Pa.However, adderall and meth are soooooo much alike. I encourage anyone out there to really think twice before putting your child on adderall. First I would get a second apinion from a Dr. who knows about addiction.2nd I would look at the families addiction history. If you must put your child on adderall I would only do so as a last option where you have tried everything else. I do not mean other drugs I mean like counseling, tuitering, sitting down with your child and helping him or her with homework. I mean really try to find out why they are having trouble focusing and try to solve the problem without a drug. Doctors are just so to quick to give you a drug or to put a lable on you. I can talk to 9 out of 10 head Dr.'s and in 15 minutes I can have them lable me anything I want them to and that is sad.I honestly believe most of life's problems are in a persons heart not our head.Please talk to your pastor as well. I think that is the first place I would start. Im talking to the man in the mirrior more than anyone and I pray someone out there knows exactly what Im saying and it's time for this great country to get back to place where we can get our hearts right with God and repent for all our sin and I truly believe our world would be a better place. If anyone out there is addicted to adderall you can get help at a place called the rolloff homes. please go to pbc-roloffhomes.org you and /or your child can get real help. no ins.needed.no money, u wont b turned away

column2: Peaches0324, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with Clinical Depression when I was 38. I've been on about 10 different antidepressants since then. I am now 53. I am doing so well on this since it was prescribed to me by my physciatrist a year ago. I take 30mg. twice a day. I now clean my house, organize my life and activities plus joined the gym. I've lost a little weight, I gained a lot on the antidepressants, and continue to slowly lose it since I've joined they gym. I've never slept much since I was diagnosed with the depression but I can now sleep a good 5 hours a night and feel rested. It does, however, make you sweat a lot. I sweat a lot anyway living in the south with the humidity, but this makes it worse. Sometimes this is a good thing. I think I need another does though. During the day after my second dose, which is late in the afternoon since I get up so early, I start to wind down too early. I still go to bed late and get up by at least 5 every morning. I've always been a morning person but I think I do need an extra dose. I'll be asking my doctor for a third pill to take during the day so I can get things done in the evening. It has helped me so much I recommend it to anyone that has depression and anxiety issues like I do. I've not had a panic attack in about three months. I've found that certain situations and people trigger those. I've learned to avoid them. Hope this helps someone in need.

column2: 19-24 Female  (Patient)
column9: A lot of people don't realize, that when you take amphetamines or stimulants, they will work AMAZING at first, but only for temporarily.  But once your body gets used to the drug, you need to increase the dosage in order for the drug to "keep working."  After being on the medication for a couple of years, the patient slowly feels like a "speeding slug", where you are feeling energetic from the drug, but disorganized where it's not getting you anywhere, but giving you anxiety.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: well I have been on Adderal for about 7 yrs.  I am now taking 240 mg a day..thats 2 30's 4 x a day.  I almost think that dosage is to high.., but when I try to cut back, it is impossible for me to do.  I'd rather take none at all (which that I cn dio easily) than just take say half the prescribed amount.  But my old habbits are back and worse. I still make my lists, ect., but I go off on so many rabit trails while doing the list, the list never gets done.  It almost takes me 3x longer to accomplish anything.  For me to pack and go to the lake, it takes me s good 6 hours.  I no all this is not how it should be..but I think i am what they call Tweaking out on it.  I think I will go aff it competely then go to 30mg x 2 a day.  One more thing.  When I don't take my adderal for a few days, when I do take it I have to start off on VERY small dosage.Thanks for all the reviews, I really showed me what I alreadty new in my heart..., plus it gave me the re3commended dosage for amount to take a day.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Adderall seems like a miracle pill at first, but like most amphetamine based drugs that aren't entirely clean... it comes with a price.First, it IS very expensive now, even though Shire doesn't even make the pill.  Teva makes the namebrand now...  also the price is now higher, even the generic XR capsule.  Dexedrine is a better drug for ADHD, but is also easily to become immune to, and you're once again, F'd.  Adderall's negative side effects were not noticed by me for almost a year.  I worked out every morning, went to class, and had baseball practice after school.  College, drinking, bad habits, and the effectiveness of the drug were all part of the problem.Ritalin or anything like Concerta will probably make you more nervous, and give you a worse headache.  So far, Dexedrine has had the least side effects but comes with a negative stigma attached to its name.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have struggled with ADHD symptoms since I can remember.  I only recently started taking medications as my symptoms got worse after having children.  I tried Ritalin before switching to Adderall.  It has helped me more than anything I have ever tried to do on my own (making schedules, writing notes & reminders, not taking on too many things at once).  It just made life so much easier.  I don't have accidents at work, I focus better, I finish what I start and dont procrastinate.  I also am able to get to work on time and not be as stressed and irritable.  However, I have been on it for two years and I have had issues with not being able to take it for a few days or a week sometimes and I definitly felt that there was a dependence even after taking the correct dosage always.  I dont like the fact that Adderall is so addictive whether you abuse it or not.  I want to be put on something else so I dont have to worry about that, but i think that the outcome outweighs the risk...unless another medication can do the same job without being as addictive physically.

column2: Bill Mc, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Male, Age 60, for Adult ADD. Taking it approx 18 months. Prescribed generic Adderall 20mg twice daily. Usually split the dose into 10mg 2 or 3 times a day. Skipping dose completely 2 days in a row each week so as to not have to increase the dosage. Works very well for me.  Helps me to focus and accomplish what ever I may be working on. Also more sociable and more tolerant of others. Good for anger management. Spouse notices the difference and supportive of my taking it. Some initial weight loss 5 - 8 lbs but have since regained it.  Just eat at meal times and try more highly seasoned food (easy on the salt).  Also drink more liquids. Best to not take it late in the day unless you plan on being up late. I still sleep at night and usually take a nap in the afternoon. Some people complain about excessive side effects and not liking the results.  Well see your MD and maybe try something else.  As for me, "it's just what the Doctor ordered".  Wish I had known about this medication years ago.  It's a real help for me. My results far outweigh any side effects, which I find to be minimal.

column9: Okay so anything that actually works can be called addictive because you actually need it to accomplish things the normal person is already getting done...I don't sleep till 1pm anymore and yes the house is clean and things are becoming more and more organized.As far as moods go (I know its not FDA approved) I take Damiana by Nature's Answer and there Black Cohosh with no adverse reactions or side effects along with my Adderall,multivitamins and fish oil and yes my husband is very happy as well.Set aside some time for the kids even if you have to take a break from the cleaning... And forget the Xanax because that will just reduce the Adderall you are taking.Try to get the doctor to give you divided doses of the Adderall instead of one large dose-it costs more but much more effective and remember when it comes to Adderall dosages sometimes less is more... column9: This med has transformed my life for the better. I had been living in utter chaos for my entire life until I began taking this drug. I had to deal with two very suspicious and discriminating doctors who were ideologically opposed to the notion of ADD! My current doctor is very supportive of the meds transformative effects, and monitors my progress very carefully. I have to go in for check ups every two months. I have been on the med for 3 years. The first year, 10mg once a day was effective, now 10mg twice a day OR 20 in the morning is what I take. The negatives are...muscle soreness, dry mouth and terrible breath, and excessive sweating. I try to go one day a week with out taking it, and it is truly a holiday- relaxing and mellow. **CAUTIONARY TALE** my husband came to abuse this drug in the last 3 years and wound up in a 12step program (thank goodness...) BUT he also has a history of drug abuse and recovery. I hide my script in the house now.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am 24 years old and have always struggled with the typical characteristics of ADD.  I cut class in highschool,cheated my way through, did everything last minute, and really missed out on my education.  I started taking adderrall in college and went from a 2.6GPA to a 3.8 in one semester.  I have been on and off the 30mgXR ever since then.  After a 6month hiatus from adderall i am now taking the non XR 20mg (pill and a half a day).  I have a love/hate relationship with this medication without a doubt.  Ive only been on it for 3 months and i have built up a tolerance.  I dont want to take more than 30mg a day because its unhealthy and only going to continue to build higher;however i am simply not getting the same effects.  I used to get a rush of euphoria,where i loved everything,everyone, and had thousands of aspirations--short and long term, i could do Anything for extended periods of time--including studying physics (ugh) for 6 hours straight......now that happyfeeling lasts maybe 45 minutes and i still have to work at reading.  i dont have the motivation to paint like i used to,go to the gym, or leave my house. Honestly all i ever do anymore is organize/clean my house and study for a couple hours.  But by 7pm i am completely wiped out, listless, detatched, irritable, edgy, apathetic, social anxiety ect.  I used to drink alcohol socially,now i drink atleast a glass of wine a day to cope with the irritability. AFter reading this,one may wonder why i wouldnt get off.....its because im addicted.  i may only have 4-5 hours of productivity and studying  (i have board exams to take) a day--but thats more than id ever get done without it.  When i wake up in the morning i feel great, for about an hour, then i get so tired i almost cant make it to the adderral bottle to get my 1st dose.  i cant imagine life without it, however its depleting my social life and increasing my risk of cardiovascular problems. I dont know what to do anymore!

column2: paintedacres, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I found out that I was ADD almost two years ago. I never figured in a million years that I was until she described my issues to a (T). I agreed to start taking this drug and in the beginning it was a shocker. I was so amazed how alert and focused I was and wished I would have had this throughout school. I did well in school due to getting beat if I didn't but I could have done a lot better and at least been able to retain the information. As an adult I have found it very hard to keep my impusliveness under control. I have issues with spending. I am not a shopaholic but I buy for other people when I know I shouldn't and I over eat very badly even when I am stuffed. I can't control it. It eats at me until I almost have a panic attack. When I buy things it is always for other people not myself. This drug has helped somewhat with that. It at least makes me think about it first. But while I am doing better with it, it still is not cured. I still struggle with the eating and the buying everyday. At first it helped with the eating quite a bit. Now after a year or so the effect has worn off and I tend to eat more than I did however not as much as it was before. My doctor says that you dont get used to the drug and need to take more. You only do if you misuse it. Well I have not misused and I can tell you it doesn't work like it did and I find myself needing to take 3 to 4 10mg pills (fast acting) when before and even now my script says to take 2. I am scared to go off the med since it is helping in my job and keeping me on track but I am scared to keep on with it and get to where I am abusing. I don't think I ever will however I am getting used to it. I am also scared to take other meds for add since a few times I have changed scripts for depression and it has messed me up.

column2: Bill, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: 60 year old male: Allows me to get along with wife, family, friends & strangers much better and more comfortably. My wife is glad it has been prescribed for me and is able to notice the change. Will start and complete projects. Even have learned to play Bridge, try that without being able to concentrate and focus. Prior to prescription I would procrastenate and/or not complete projects without a struggle. Retired early due to feeling overwhelmed by employment responsibilities.  Although most would say I have been a modest success, I always found it difficult to work, most routine daily activeties and just getting along.  Wish this medication had been prescribed for me many years sooner. My prescription: 20mg twice daily. I usually only take 10mg twice daily (sometimes full dosage if I have to be up late in a social setting - weddings, going out with friends, etc.) and I try to skip dose for two days in a row each week. This seems to allow the medication to work better when I take it and may prevent having to increase future dosages. Side effects minimal for me.  I still eat but sometimes not as much - no great weight loss, about 5-8 pounds. Will go to sleep but may wake up during the night but am also able to get up and get moving in the morning.  I am still able to take a short snooze in the afternoon, which I like to do. A great medication for me but I see others have not always had the same success. My suggestion, try a smaller dose a couple of times a day and take a break from it once in a while. Ask your MD.  Good Luck.  PS:  I had been prescribed Paxil for about 10 years. This was only moderately successful for me and I was glad when I stopped it, which did have a couple of withdrawl symptoms for me. Never would consider it again.  Should have tried Adderall from the start.

column2: tklawsonpharmtech, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Caregiver)
column9: Over seven Yrs. ago, Dx w/ ADD (no hyperactivity component) but lethargy, procrastination, incomplete tasks, hypersomnia, low energy, depression not well amaliarated w/ SSRI's or similar Tx. Slowly titrated, a gradual marked improvement in every catagory-and some not mentioned above. Within < 1 Yr. truly remarkable effectivness beyond expectation. Even after seven Yrs. improvement continues-and personnally, for me at least, the increments of highly complex retention is-even many fold. Today- myself, unrelenting. Well tolerated, Adderall increased the cumulative component of technical and organizational skills. NO boundries in relation to unrestricted FURTHUR clinical cognitive retentive upswing-NO decline-only MORE and better results to report to this day. The titration of tailored tid dosing most amenable to tapering, titration as needed PRN. Occational drug holidays not reflective of lost productivity or ANY inclination to increase the dose on my own initiative. Not 'habit-forming' if taken as a regimen of maintanance properly taken as directed. Note: most psychiatrists/neurologists wish the Pt's would adhere to the Dr's dosage in respect to adherance of completion of the total daily amount. Most report underuse as the only negative regimen adherance (via Adderall Pt.) by dispensing practictioner.

column9: I took Adderall Oral for a couple of years.   It seemed like the effect wore off quickly, and I was often jittery sometimes to the point of feeling like I was having a heart attack.  Also, ADDers often have a problem with forgetfulness.  About 50% of the time I either forgot to take my afternoon dose, or when I did remember, I found that I had forgotten to bring my medication with me. About year and a half ago I switched to Adderall RX Oral.  What a difference! That drug has greatly improved the quality of my life. Sometimes I forget I even have ADD. Recently my prescription drug plan changed its rules so that they will cover the regular Adderall for $10, but instead of charging $10 as they had before now charge $265 for the RX.  RX is great. All I can say about the regular Adderall is that is better than nothing, but not by much. Please note that both drugs are generic.

column2: 7-12 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My son is in 4th grade & had extreme difficulties at school such as focus,comprehension,accumulating info, disorganized,not being able to finish the work in class, math, etc. He was also diagnosed a couple of years ago with DAMP. He was on Ritalin for a couple of months 2 yrs ago & stopped since we did not see any improvement. we were at the point of desperation & had enough frustrations & so did he!Therefore eventhough I was very much against drugs we decided that he needs help so let's give it another try! His dr. prescribed Adderall 10mg/day in the AM before breakfast- a miracle has been brought upon my son & our family!! it works wonderful, amazing! the only side affects that I noticed are the loss of appetite (which I am not too upset over since he is about 6 lbs. overweight & noticed that he is hungry in AM, so I give him a healthy breakfast) and sensitivity (he easily cries if someone gets him upset).Other than that there have been no other side affects. we are all extremely happy to see him do extremely well at school. He was never hyper, but had some behavior problems - even that has changed for the better.  He interacts & socialized better w/friends. Prior to this med his grades were Cs and Ds; ever since he started on Adderall the test results are amazing; A's in social studies and B+ in math!!  Not only that it makes everyone happy (his family as well as teachers)that he's doing so well but he is very well aware of it & I can see the happiness that he did not have before when he comes home with good grades & ease at learning!! He has built confidence & holds his head up high!! Thank you Dr. Weidner!!!...& of course Adderall!  I shall return & review this med in a couple of month & let everyone know if he's still doing just as well and/or if the side affects have changed!

column2: a3gill, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Adderall has been a lifesaver. I took Ritalin as a kid and developed some nervous ticks. So, I dropped it, and tried to manage without. I did fine until college reading emerged.I have a ridiculously high dosage, but it works great for me, other than nasty looks that I get from Pharmacists thinking that I am a dealer.(that buys inventory with insurance...LOL) My dosage is steady now, but for about the first year, it was increased each month. Thats probably just me though, my body doesnt respond well to medicine.Reading comprehension has always been my biggest hurdle, non-technical reading is virtually impossible for me. Just below reading is hanging-in with poor lecturers. I need to have genuine interest in something or my mind will promptly begin to wander. If a teacher shows the end goal and it appears interesting, then the uninteresting stepping stones become interesting, because they are required to get to the concept that you want to know. Conversely, if a teacher presents each building block as something to know, "because I said so," then I will be staring out the window before they finish their sentence.Since arriving at the correct dosage, I can now do anything that I want. Not only are my problem areas fixed, but other aspects have improved as well. The best way that I can describe it is having a librarian roaming around in your brain. My capacity for learning has gone off the charts, my memory retention and recollection is ridiculous, and the boost of energy really shines though in self-motivation. And, above all, I now spend at least 2-4 hours per day reading anything that I want.To put my improvement in context, I took my ACTs un-medicated. My best score was a 29/36.Hmm, its okay, but look at the pieces:Math: 36/36Science Reasoning: 35/36English: 32/36Reading: 14/36I noticed the benefits most, when I lost them with my insurance for a month. Not withdraw symptoms, having to deal with my old flawed brain. I was spoiled.

column9: I was VERY concerned about medicating behaviors, since I don't even take aspirin. NOW I can FINALLY complete tasks in a timely fashion, organize and order my work and life and enjoy relationships, both personal and professional, as well as attend to details. column2: Rocco, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Adderall has been an extremely effective drug for managing my ADD symptoms. Before being started on adderall, I found it difficult if not impossible to stay focused on most tasks, especially if the task was not something that i was interested in doing. With the medication however, I find it much easier to keep my mind on topic, allowing me to utilize my time and energy with much more efficiency and efficacy. My biggest complaint with adderall has been its effect on sleep. However, I found that if I take my last dose at least 9 hours before I intend to sleep it causes little to no problem.

column9: Well first of all I was not have to begin this medication at the age of 32. I have just started this medication. I had eaten about 6 hours earlier and hadn't had any of the drug in about 12 hours. I've had headaches and the jitters. They say this will pass. I'm trying to keep hydrated and take my vitamins. I'm only on the 5mg dose and have to bump up to the 10mg dose after 15 days, and I'm worried about further side effects. I know there are ADD drugs that are non-narcotic and plan to ask my psychiatrist about that option. On a good note it has begun to control my irritability and my impulsiveness (I'm known to intetrrupt and not be able to wait my turn to speak or not filter my thoughts and just blurt out thoughts) I do not have ADHD, I believe I have simple ADD and it runs in the family. Luckily my daughter doesn't seem to have many symptoms and does well in school. I just hope that the increase in dose does not give me too many side effects and I am worried that my tabacco use may increase my chance of a cardiac event. I do not like the feeling of my heart racing. I'm also taking an SSRI and worried about those side effects, my MD is aware. I'm just worried in general.

column2: Happy Mom, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed at a very early age,(nursery school) and my parents were against any medication to deal with the problem. They instead sent me to a private school with smaller classes and kept having me tested throughout my school years and kept getting the same answers. I would not pay attention in class and was very disruptive. They would yelled at me after meetings with my teachers and ground me. It was not my fault. As I matured I was able to graduate from college but I had a very hard time focusing. I have been on Adderol and Vivanse for about a year now and I cant believe my parents put me through a miserable childhood when I could have been much more "normal" and been able to focus with the medication. I have not experienced any bad side effects from either meds and I am much more happy and less stressed.

column2: doria1968, 3-6 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My 4 and a half yr old started this medication about two weeks ago.  At first, it would make him drowsey in the morning, he'd take a nap, then seemed less defiant for awhile, then he would crash and come down and have like these meltdowns late afternoon.  Today, however, was another story.  Doesn't make him tired anymore, instead it was like hearing and watching a robot:  over and over repeating things like, "You hate me.....you hate me....you hate me...you don't like me...you don't like me...you want to throw me in the dumpster..."  Over and over for like an hour.  We see his doctor tomorrow, but I'm not giving him this stupid pill, I'm not about to go thru that again!  That was awful!  It was not my child, it was like someone else crawled inside him and was saying these awful things.  Then I made him take a nap, and he was back to himself.  Very sweet and apologizing like crazy, and playing with Thomas trains.  He's good in school regardless whether he's on meds or not.  This is our first experience with meds.  But home is like being in prison, he's a completely different child (without the meds, too).  I've been reading on others, and I"m confused.  I'm afraid to give him something else, what if the behavior's worse?  I'm worried about having some serious aggressive behavior with time. Then I suffer depression and anxiety on top of all this.  We're both in therapy, but toy therapy is not the answer!  I don't know what to expect, I'm afraif for my child.

column2: NikiM1973, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Since taking Adderall I consistently do the right things at the right time. Before Adderall I struggled with moments of genius followed by days of a mixture of procrastination and chaos. With Adderall my focusing abilities are quite amazing. I have to actually be careful to not over-focus. I can honestly get so hooked on the details of a particular work project that I find myself working for 12+ hours without much of a break. So with that said I should probably urge everyone to try to maintain a life of balance. I've always been good at what I do, but now I can do more with less. I eat less. I sleep less. I waste time less. I make mistakes less. I'm more patient. I'm overall much happier. Am I addicted to it? Yes. When I don't take it I'm an even bigger disaster than before. If I don't take it I could stay in bed all day and stare at the TV. For me, the Adderall PROS outweight the CONS. If you are a distracted mess with piles of papers, a racing mind, and an inability to put first things first then I suggest you talk with your doctor about trying a low dose for starters. I've been taking Adderall for about 4 years and I take 40 mg daily, in the form of two (2) 20mg tablets. I do not like the XR (extended release) formulation of any medication, so it is not specific to Adderall.

column2: NEPABelle, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I started Adderall when I was 20.Up to that point I had been on everything under the sun for my ADD since primary school - from Ritalin to antianxiety meds like Xanax, and every antidepressant inbetween. After trying so many of the 'popular' drugs, my psych. decided that we should try Adderall -I was a little unnerved about the drug after reading all of the negative things about it online but decided that, as a last resort, I'd give it a try.I COULD NOT BE HAPPIER! This month is my 15th on the drug, and I've only noticed minor, appetite related side effects. [Perhaps it's because I am on a lower dose (20mg every morning and one 10mg at noon)?] Over all, I've noticed my focus is so much better, along with my ability to finish the things I start. My mind isn't going, going, going all the time, and I was finally able to get a job, and go back to school!  I understand the concern with younger children taking this medication, however, everyone reacts differently to different things, and if there were any natural alternative that would work, I'd be the first one on it. [I had tried going off of it and went right back to not being able to sit still for more than 15mins.] From my experience with Adderall, I've realised that sometimes, some perscriptions are necessary to lead a normal, quiet life.I know that the results aren't the same for everyone on it, but I did want to share a positive outcome :D

column2: rebecca, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Have been able to stay focused and finish the tasks I've started.

column2: ADDgirl, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have ADD and probably have been since a least a pre-teen[self-diagnosis] but haven't been professionally diagnosed until 3 months ago at age 33.  I am currently on 25mg of Adderall, 1 pill daily in AM.  The 10mg & 20mg did nothing for me in terms of concentration but I am noticing better results with the 25mg, though I think it needs to be upped.  Only one time I was up 32 straight hours but that was partially due to having to be in school that night as well as the first increase from 20mg - 25mg. I had problems sleeping before taking this drug and I still do, though I CAN sleep through the night. I have experienced weight loss and lack of appetite with sometimes being repulsed by food.  I crave more water now.  This hasn't been a problem since I am obese, and I have lost almost 20 lbs in 3 months.  I no longer crave a lot of junk foods and eat more healthy since snacking isn't as frequent.  My job tasks and school work have greatly improved!  I wish my mom wouldn't have just told me to apply myself better in school and actually had me evaluated.  I don't feel like a failure anymore with this new outlook and I am finally at peace knowing about this "disability".

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I am 22 and i have been on adderall since i was 14. This drug is insanely addictive and thats what I hate about it. Sure it works, makes you focus, you can go without sleep easier then others, it makes you lose weight (i myself lost 55 pounds), and it makes you more sociable with others. But the price you pay is that you become dependent on it. Why would you want a drug to do all the work for you? It's going to cause health problems, most likely cardiac, if not now, in the future. You'll have to stay on it forever (my doctor literally said that i would have to take it forever, im not kidding), and if you find it in yourself to quit, you'll hate the world when you go off of it. i tried to quit 4 years ago, got off of it for a year, and i couldn't take it, i had to get back on it. In my eyes, people do cocaine or meth for reasons similar to adderall. They need to stay up and get things done, feel happy, and they are addicted. Don't get on it. Learn to focus the old fashioned way. Because you'll still get that diploma, or certification, or acheive happiness and at the end of it all, you wont feel like you cheated or owe it all to adderall, you'll just be proud of yourself and have no dependencies. Thats soo much better and I really wish my parents would have just given me that option. Oh and one more thing, females have to get off of it when you get pregnant and thats scary to go through withdrawls and then go and be pregnant. I just had an early miscarriage... dont know that it has to do with this drug, but i dont know that it doesn't..

column2: mindfocused, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am a 38 year old male.  I have suffered my whole life with ADHD/ADD.  I never knew or understood why I behaived the way I did, until my son showed the same symptoms and was diagnosed.  I asked my doctor about my symptoms and he recommended a low 20mg a day dosage.  I did not sleep for 3 days, I thought my heart would burst, but in three days, I read 4 books, all 400+ pages.At work, my productivity increased instantly. Instead of looking for the door, and at the clock, "bouncing off the walls" as my co-workers would tell me, I was focused, task orriented, and results driven.  My district VP, who I have known for over 10 years, even called and asked me, why my team is doing so well.  I have been on this drug for 6 months now, and it has helped me to change my life! I have my blood pressure checked regularly, I excercise more, because I can focus and not get bored out of my mind in 3 minutes, I eat better, because I can read labels and know what it is I am eating, because my mind is not changing thoughts every 2 seconds and I forget what the HELL I was reading to begin with, my wife LOVES ME, because I am focused when she talks to me and I can actually carry a conversation with her, because I can remember what she just said.  And you know what else, I actually sat down and wrote this message in just a few minutes.  I did not even get up, or even think about anything else, I did not have to stretch, scratch, move, fidget, adjust, look around, yawn, cough, or ANYTHING, because this drug helped me. I thanked my doctor, and I cried when I did, because I have awakened, my mind does not race, and after 38 years of life, my mind is clear.

35-44 Female  (Patient)
column9: I am 38 yr old mother of two. My experience is the time release(XR) is the best form the non time release feels like you are on a roller coaster.  The time release is very smooth.  Although I started on 20mg I believe after 5 years on this and now down to 5mg a day this is a very hard drug on my body as a women.  I have two best friends on it and although we love the weight it keeps off and how organized we think we are on it we all believe there is a dark side to this drug that no one talks about. Everyone seems OK in our lives except our husbands.  There is an edgy/anger piece that goes along with this drug..  I think it effects our hormones in some way.  My suggestion is start on a lower dose and move up but I am looking for more natural choices because I think this drug makes life go by very quickly.  I also think as a women you can not help but get addicted to the way you burn more calories and it automaticly suppresses your appetite.  If you are on this and are having relationship problems then you might want to look at this drug as a reason and not other outside things. Also I think if you take the wrong dose it can actually make it harder to complete some things. This drug is in the same family as Meth amphedemines.  If you take this drug you should really think about the similarities to being a junkie!! I stopped taking it for 6 months and gained 30 pounds and I started sleeping a lot and my house became a disaster.  There is probably something better out there, but I have not found it.

19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: It works, it really does. Unfortunately, I became HIGHLY ADDICTED to this medication. I am 21 and a university student and have been on adderall since i was 19. In just two years i developed a 100mg+ habit per day, ended up literally going crazy, cutting, attempting suicide, committed to a psychiatric hospital, and then drug and alcohol rehab. Since I kicked adderall, I have been just fine. Kids won't tell you anything is wrong, because it makes them feel so good they want it more. It severely disrupts eating habits (I lost 35lbs, and as a 5'2" female, that's a lot), sleeping habits, and overall mood. I also found a sharp decline in imagination and overall creativity. Irritability, dehydration, diarrhea, malnutrition, anemia, and withdrawals were part of my adderall use that was prescribed by a psychiatrist for ADHD. PLEASE, if you are a parent wondering if your kid should be on adderall (which is an amphetamine salt, which is the single purest form of SPEED), think again. Is it worth it in the long run? It is SPEED that you're messing with here- incredibly serious drug. There are many many more behavioral modifications that can be taught that are much more effective, and MUCH MUCH less detrimental to overall mental and physical health. NOT WORTH IT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

column2: narcolepsyslife, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: History: I have had the symptoms of narcolepsy since childhood. First memories I can recall is around 5 years of age. I did not get it officially diagnosed until I was 50 years old.  I knew the stigma of Narcolepsy would interfere with job searching. I am now on a base prescription of adderall and adderall XR combination at 160mg per day. At times the ranges may go as far up to 240mg or down to only several.  All is depended on the days requirements.  I also try to take 1-2 days of Adderall free days to lessen the problem of drug tolerance.  The adderall still at the high dose performs very poorly in managing my microsleeps. I am also on Xyrem treatments for the last 5 months.  Xyrem is not working very well.  I have been diagnosed as a right clinical context narcolepsy.  I unfortunately am one of the exceptions to the effectiveness of amphetamines and the like. Even from the beginning, the amphetamines have had little effect on my body. History:  I was never a drug user and I never liked to drink alcohol. I still don't drink or use recreational drugs.  Never had any of the 'so called side effects' that amphetamines can give someone at the higher dose. In the past I have had provigil and ritlan with no effective treatment. If the above appears to be disassociated, I had more than several microsleep episodes trying to get this written.

column9: Taking Adderall XR with suboxone makes a pill cocktail. The high from those two drugs combined is a whole new ball game. First of all Docs know nothing but to see you on your appointment and then get rid of you. If they payed any attention they would know that a person with a history of drug or alcohol abuse should not take adderall or adderall xr. But then again they keep us coming back for business. So, would that make them a legal drug dealer. Yes, it would. I had a chemical dependency to perscription painkillers. I realized something was really bad when I was taking them just to be able to function from day to day. I sought help because things were all jacked up. If I could make a difference in someone's life just by writing this little piece then all the pain I caused myself and everyone around me, then I would have to say it was worth it. If you have a chemical dependency the first thing you do is decide weather or not you want to continue that way of life, which is extremely painful. Second, commit to yourself in getting well. You will need a really good support system to help you through it. With hard work and dedication to yourself you will succeed. If you follow those three rules you will get through it with out a dought. If I had to go through it again I would have gone to the psychiatrist to get on suboxone so I could wing myself through it. I was on suboxone for one year exactly. If I would have just listened to my brother and not got on the suboxone I would have gotten over the emotional withdrawl after about 5 to 7 days. The physical withdrawls(tiredness,unmotivated)would eventually pass around three to four weeks. So, you could get through it in a months time verses getting on suboxone and wasting a year of your life.

column9: I've struggled with ADD my entire life but my parents were totally against medicating me (thank you mom and dad) Instead they made an effort to get me help from tutors and personal coaches that taught me good organizational and study habits which helped a bit. I struggled all through out my 6 years of college and now at 26, moving into the ranks of working for myself and taking on several projects, I could really use some help. My buddy gave me some adderall and I probably got more work done in 2 weeks than my 6 years of college- mainly because I neither ate nor slept for days at time. I also found that I was able to pop these like skittles with frightening ease. I couldn't see taking this medication daily as I wouldn't risk my physical and psychological well-being for any amount of work or money. I believe this should be used as a last resort. One thing I have learned is to observe my work habits while on adderall vs. when I'm not and try to mimic those behaviors daily. This drug is certainly a tool for success but I feel that it shouldn't be used as a way of living.

column2: absent_minded, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was started out on 20mg of Adderall Oral daily (in the morning). But currently, my dosage has been increased to 30 mg each morning, with the option to take another 10 to 20 mg later on in the day during long work days. I have an ADHD sufferer's worst nightmare for a job: I'm mostly a paper-pusher/interviewer. I'm a social worker for a corrections department. I have piles of paperwork everyday. I also teach decision-making and social skills classes, which also require a lot of planning and organization. I had been able to negotiate with and compensate for my ADHD all through grade schools, high school, and college. However, my condition became dibillitating at my first "career" job with the massive amounts of paperwork and organization I was expected to perform. I'm in my early 20s and began treatment for ADHD at the beginning of August. I feel that the medication has helped me immensely. My family, fiance, and coworkers have all noticed the change in my work habits and all-around behavior. I'm quieter, more focused, and less apt to "fly off the handle" for minor things that don't seem to make much sense to anyone else. I'm pretty satisfied overall with my results. That said, I do experience some side effects. I have had pretty significant loss of appetite as well as weight loss. But for me, its not a major issue at the moment as I was already considered somewhat overweight by my doctor when I started the medication. If I continue to lose at this rate, I suppose it could become a problem. I also experience dry mouth pretty badly. I sometimes get it so bad that my whole mouth feels "fuzzy." But luckily, I'm allowed to keep a drink on my desk at work :) Also, I occasionally experience headaches that I believe are related to the medication. But these aren't very often. All in all, there's some drawbacks/side effects, but the benefits far outweight them.

column2: Namebadgerequired, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with ADD at age 41, and prescribed 20mg 1x/day. It helped a little but not enough to cause me to really follow a treatment track with enthusiasm...typical ADD. Anyway, I am now 46; I have had 4 different employers in that time, plenty of stress, depression, anxiety, low self esteem, etc. Three years ago, I had the double sleep study which revealed that I have narcolepsy. So now, my sleep specialist has me taking 30mg XR in the morning, and Adderall tabs of 20mg at 9am/noon/3pm for a total of 90mg/day. I have gone through highs and lows with this drug - more highs than lows. I think that the biggest drag in this whole process is that Adderall is just a daytime life support system for my exhaustion; it does enable me to focus, hustle, retain instructions, etc. But - I still have an incurable sleep disorder which never allows me to get restorative sleep. I am definitely addicted to Adderall; I get anxious when my doctor goes on vacation because he has done it in the past, without notice! Needless to say, I am changing doctors. Finally, I can relate to people that complain about the zombie effect. I have a great ability to entertain my family and friends with my humor, and sometimes it will just disappear for days. My new doctor said that he is worried about my heart; I told him that I am at peace with "death by heart attack". He was not amused. I wasn't trying to be funny, just pragmatic. I need my Adderall and I think it works great for the right patient.

column2: TheDoc, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Caregiver)
column9: As a Doctor myself, I have to stress that when it comes to Adderall in either the XR or IR forms, there is no grey area. There are those patients who do extremely well on this medication and others who were perhaps misdiagnosed or physiologically intolerant of the chemical makeup of the drug. The bottom line is: If you need it, it can work wonders. However, if you're one of those who doesn't truly suffer from ADD ADHD-Hyp, then you may gain some benefits, but you will also have more incidence of negative side-effects. My personal experience with the IR has been wonderful. Most everyone has the associated loss of appetite, and general "fidgety" feeling when starting treatment, but these do subside. However, they have a nasty habit of resurfacing later on in treatment. This usually accompanies an increase in dosage, but can pop up for seemingly no reason at all. The best advice I can give regarding treatment with amphet salts is: If you need it, then it can help tremendously. However, if you don't need it, you're better off with those awful energy drinks or a few cups of coffee. Hope this helps.

Parent, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: My 18 year old son was recently diagnosed with attention deficite disorder...with no real apparent symptoms.  Our family doctor decided it would help him concentrate in college.  Immediately I noticed that a generally tender-hearted,goodnatured young man became cruel, moody and for lack of a better definition psychotic.  He started abusing alcohol, risky sexual behavior, and would lie about anything.  It was like a alien had taken over my son's body.  It has been a nightmare and I would never encourage any parent to give this drug to their children.  My son has been off of it for about 1 week and right now he is a fragile shell who has suffered with depression, vomiting, headaches etc.  My hope for his once bright future now rests on his ability to overcome an apparent addiction and not to be drawn back down that road.  This is not anything you want to put into your body.  I feel like my only son has been taken from me and I don't know if I will ever get that same bright eyed, enthusiatic young man back.

column9: i am a 16 year old. I started taking adderall at the age of twelve. When i was on the drug it was very effective. column2: David7, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I Have been taking this medication for a little over a year now.  I was diagnosed with ADD as a child, but I not took the medication.  I am 35 now and am a small business owner.  I was making small, little stupid mistakes that I just easily overlooked.  My Dr. started me off with 30mg twice a day. I have seen these reviews and have yet to see someone taking that much.  I had all of the the effects for about a month and then they all eventually went away.  The drug overall has improved my attention disorder and even made me more productive.  It allowed all of my energy to be creative.  I still use it today at the same dosage but I found it better for me to take 60mg in the morning and let it run its course through the day.  If you do need to take it. Remember that every ones body responds differently to medication.  I suggest to experiment the time gaps in the beginning and see what best responds to your body.  You will become addicted to it after a while, no choice in that, but just use your months supply evenly.  It has been a success and I researched this med.. I accept the cons of this medication, but for me "someone who really needs it" the pros weigh out the cons.  it has made me more productive with my life and for my family responsibilities. If you "REALLY" are not diagnosed by a physician. Please remember that you will get a reverse effect and it will be equivalent to taking cocaine.  But for those who need it it will have a reverse effect and make you more focused and in a clear state of mind, without the million things around you distracting you from your realistic goal.Good Luck and Be Wise! Parents, Be alert of your kid on this if applicable, it is becoming a known street DRUG for abuse. Thanks!

column9: I am junior in high school and have been taking adderall for 3 years. At first it seemed like a miracle drug. My grades went up considerably and I felt that I had gained a sense of control. I was prescribed 30mg a day including one 20mg pill of adderall xr. The side effects were harsh in the beginning and I lost a lot of weight. The next 2 years I would take it regularly still having the same side effects but very mild. In short, I could go off the pill and feel fine for any amount of time. But I began to feel a sort of dependence on the drug about a year after. The loss of appetite seemed to be a motivation for me to be thin so i started to up my dose a little bit. My grades went from a 3.3 to a 2.7 and so i figured I was immune to the drug so I started to take even more. For the past about 6 months I have regularly been taking at the least 50mg and at most 70mg a day. Sometimes I don't know why I am taking it I just do. I can honestly say in the past week I have slept in total maybe 10-15 hours some nights not sleeping at all. My heart is constantly pounding and my hands are always shaking. I hate it but i can't help it. My parents dont hide my pills or anything and dont keep track of when they get it so it makes it easy for me.I am always very moody and today I had a nutri grain bar and thats it but I dont even feel hungry. I didnt think drugs prescribed to myself could be so addictive but they are. I suggest people not to take them to begin with.

column2: bratz, 13-18 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: worked good at first.  Major mood swings after a while

column2: figrditout, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Adderall since last November (08).  I was started on 20mg of Adderall xr, then went to 25 mg xr, and now I take 25mg xr in the morning around 6am, and then an Adderall IR, 10mg, around noon to one p.m.  I think Adderall works great, the problem I had was that even though it is an XR formulation it seemed to wear off around noonish everyday.  I was never able to get "all day coverage".  In February my doctor added the 10mg IR "booster" and it has worked great ever since.  He told me that every one's body metabolism is different and some get longer coverage than others.  This is what worked for me.  I was worried about sleep issues being on this dose, the amazing thing is I actually feel like I sleep better since being on this medication.  When I lay down to go to sleep I don't have a million and one things floating through my head like I use to.  It's like the background "white noise" is gone.  My thoughts are so much clearer now and I can actually get things accomplished instead of 20 things half accomplished.  It's too bad people abuse this drug, it's makes it more difficult for people who use it for legitimate medical purposes to get it.  All of my other medications I can get a 90 day supply in the mail.  With Adderall I have to go to my doctors office every month and pick up my prescription in person.  Other than that absolutely no complaints.  Good luck to all.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I began taking Adderall 10mg three months ago once or twice a day.  I work full time and am in graduate school.  I also train significantly (20+ hours weekly) for 10K races and triathlons.  So to put it lightly, I am a busy bee.  Adderall has allowed me to focus on one task at a time, improve my work projects, write papers, and train harder.  With regards to side effects, I do have a significantly lowered appetite and can experience issues falling asleep at night if I take a second dose after about 3:00 in the afternoon.  I also would consider going up to 15mg twice daily in the next couple months, so I feel that the drug builds a tolerance quite quickly.Adderall has changed my outlook on daily life.  It has improved my focus.  I finally feel excited about my life and living it!

column2: JustSomeThoughts, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Without a doubt this is an effective drug however it is powerful and has potentially serious side effects.  I've taken adderral for a few years now and it has been a tremendous study and work aid.  Those who take it must be careful due to the outright strength of this stuff.  For about a year I would say that I was addicted to adderral.  I would take too much, too often and get more from friends when I ran out.  During this time I had extreme mood swings, anxiety, loss of sexual interest ability, etc.  Plain and simple I was not myself at all.  I lost weight and I felt as if my personality changed.  After realizing the dilema I stopped taking it for a bit and got healthy.  Now I take the recommended dosage on the prescibed schedule.  It is effective and since I am aware of the side effects I make sure that I am eating right, sleeping enough, etc.  All and all it is an effective drug however those taking it should be very mindful of the possible downside.  Finally, I do not like most children should take this drug, and none should do so in high doses.  If children cannot do anything without the aid of medication, then they will be dependant on this stuff their whole like.  I still function and get work done in a demanding job with or without adderall.

column2: Niecie, 45-54 Female  (Patient)
column9: I am a 49 yr female... I always knew I was differrent. I felt like information went into my brain but went right out the other side. I would read, listen to a lecture or be in a conversation and end with no recollection of the information I was given. How was I to explain this to a doctor... I thought they would think I was crazy. I rehearsed over and over what I would say to them to make them believe there truely was a problem. How much easier it would be to go in and show them a cut, bruise or broken bone... they could fix it. How could they diagnose or fix a problem they couldn't see and I couldn't explain. I spent 7 years in and out of the doctors office. She first put me on prozac, treated me for an inter-ear infection, had me get all of my old fillings replaced, got glasses,treated me for allergies, etc. All these things were good but there was still something much more. She gave up, one day she said "I can't help you". Talk about a heart break and a validation that I was crazy. One day I read an ad on Straterra... explaining the symptoms of adult ADHD. I asked my doctor if there were special test for that. She said yes, as she rolled her eyes, but she would have to refer me to a shrink...here we ago again! The psycologist had me diagnosed in moments. No special tests were needed. The Straterra has helped for about 6 years now but there was still something more that I couldn't put my finger on. I have been going to doctors now for another 3 years to finally get one to take my extreme fatigue seriously. I took a sleep test and I have mild narcolepsy. My doctor has recently added adderall and I am finally content that what I have been silently struggling with all my life has been discovered and properly treated. I breaks my heart to pieces to think I raised my 3 children without this help. I struggled so badly just to make it through each day and hide my feelings of "stupidness". Now at almost 50, I feel like I have a clear mind...and a new start on life.

column2: tm0826, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed adderall 10 mg bid for excessive daytime sleepiness last year/summer. It worked wonders for me. Kept me very alert more focused. Only side effects I had was a little shakey, mild high blood pressure but only when I first took it, and higher resting pulse rate. I also had lack of appetite which I thought was a plus. And weight loss. I lost my job and couldnt continue to take my adderall. I was back to my sleepy fatigue ways it was horrible. So I was dying to go back on the adderall plus I had gained about 30 lbs!!!So I have now been back on the adderall 10 mg bid and my side effects have gotten worse. I feel the med works like it did before but my b/p is high sometimes 150/100 and my resting pulse is 90-100. I sometimes get "pangs" of pain in my chest like 2-3 times a day and I have shortness of breath sometimes. Like I need to take a deep breath. It is making me nervous. I think my b/p was a little high before I started adderall so not sure if its directly the adderall.I do have loss of appetite again but have not lost any weight. Which sucks!! But I have only been on adderall for about a month. So maybe I just didnt lose it yet.When I first started taking the meds last summer I did sometimes take up to 40 mg in one day.I know Im not supposed to but I would if I wanted to study or get up early the next day. My fatigue/sleepiness gets so bad sometimes I physically cant get up in the morning. And sometimes I can sleep like a whole day. So maybe thats why I lost more weight, too. Has anyone else had these side effects that I am now having? I have an app. with my primary physician this week for the high b/p. Just to make sure all is ok. Im only 30 yrs old and dont want heart probs.now!! But I like the adderall and hope I can stay on it.

I have horrible tirade mood swings, I don't feel like I am getting more work done during the day, I focus on things that are not a priority,like ebay. I also leave the office so exhausted I feel like I have lost me. I have no energy to do anything. Errands are a big deal, working out, forget it. I feel like I have no time, because I waste a lot of it. Procrastinating. It is ruining my life. The only good thing is it keeps my hunger at bay, and my weight is at 120. I wonder if I was off all these meds how I would be. I am 41 and feel like a 90 year old taking a bunch of pills each day. column9: I come from an good middle class, educated family and discovered that I was ADD recently.  I am a high school teacher, an athlete and a father of a beautiful 5 year old autistic child. column2: Garfila, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: This is a Reply to the woman who posted a question on 3/20/09.... Edema (Swelling/Fluid) in the ankles & feet is a seriouse side effect from Adderal and indicates a circulatory problem (blood flow) usually due to a heart problem. Most likely a temporary side effect but a serious one. If you stop taking the drug, symptoms should go away unless serious damage has been done or it's poss it could be related to another condition or a drug/food interaction with Adderall. Call your doctor/pharmacist. Also, Review drug info on WebMD.

column9: 3/26/2009:Adderall review.  I am 59 years old. Very satisfied. Sometimes I have a slight headache, which is not distracting and only very mild pain. column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Adderall for almost 2 years now. I like the XR pills MUCH better than the fast acting pills, but can no longer afford them due to recently losing my job and health insurance. I used to take 25mg (XR) in the morning and that worked well, and I noticed less side effects.  Now I take 10mg of the generic amphetamine salts 2 x's a day. Since starting on the medication I have less difficulty prioritizing my day and schedule, retaining information, starting and finishing tasks, and paying attention in general. On the other hand, I have developed nervous habits I can't break like biting my lips, playing with my nails and a crazy desire to smoke, feel awkward in certain social situations (which is TOTALLY not me), feel edgy and moody at the end of most days, and sometimes have trouble making fast decisions and conveying my thoughts clearly. Over all, I feel the benefits of the drug outweigh the negative side effects (I used to be a total spaz and be asked almost daily if I was "on crack", which really messed with my self esteem) so I continue to take it, but I cant help but wonder if I should try something else.  Any suggestions?

column2: Kaylee, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was very pleased with Adderall for about 2 months. My brain finally woke up, I could focus and get things done, I had energy, I would gladly do dreaded tasks, and I finally felt normal. Then after 2 or 3 months, it was not so effective. At 4 months my doctor increased the dosage from 10 MG to 15 MG twice a day. The outcome: I broke out in a rash on my stomach and sides by the end of day 1. Even after stopping Adderall for 5 days and starting back up on only 5 MG twice a day, the itching and rash would return. Will someone tell me why this reaction might occur? I do take a small amount of thyroid medication for a slightly underactive thyroid (Armour Thyro 30 MG), but I do not think that is the problem. I have also been on hormone replacement therapy for the past 5 years. I would be lost without Adderall to help with my ADHD. I have suffered from this condition for years, and for me it has only gotten worse with age. I tried Strattera about 4 years ago and it had far too many adverse side effects.  Any suggestions will be greatly appreciated...

column2: beckelly, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I am 22 years old but have suffered with ADD for years..starting in 5th grade i got tested for learning disabilities every year and got the same answer back i was fine... I struggled through school getting frustrated with everything because i literally couldnt do it... The summer before my senior year in highschool i suffered major depression and got sent to a very intelligent psychiatrist and after 30mins with him he diagnosed me with ADD and put me on adderal my senior year i got all A's and B's with earlier years left me barley passing if i passed at all.. putting aside the frustration of it taking almost my whole school career not knowing and struggling adderal completly changed my life and helped me fulfill many dreams..i am now in college taking courses to get a degree in accounting and I will finish is August...I am still taking adderal and have been on the presidents list having a 3.8 GPA the whole time! It has helped me so much and would recommend it to anyone who seems to struggle with ADD!

column2: LOLALOVE, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I sought help when I found it nearly impossible to sit and concentrate on my school work. My mind was everywhere, I had no motivation to do the work, couldn't explain why. My ADHD is.. well, I am hyperactive just to the extent that I find I am always moving something, just slightly, for instance like wiggling my toes. I'm also the daydreamish type, which isn't easy in college. Benefits of Adderall, in my case, included more energy, increased focus, increased calm, and an increased ability to express what I had to say because my thoughts weren't as scattered. I could follow the teacher easier in class, things made much more sense.. it was as if my mind was on steroids or something. Like steroids, Adderall had its side effects too, which in my case included mood changes when it wore off (I heard Adderall XR prevents that, but haven't tried), but I'm talking extreme irritability, and normally I am not like that at all.. so personality changes.. I kept to myself, felt my empathy leave, feelings and emotions numbed SIGNIFICANTLY. felt dead inside. Sure, I could concentrate on whatever I CHOSE, and I didn't magically want to do school work, that's the catch. If you're like me, you still have to make that conscious decision to do the work.. and once you do decide to, it is a heck of a lot easier to concentrate. If you start the doses do so slowly.. when I was on too high a dose, I felt so stressed, had high blood pressure, & I was angry, & too concentrated. Please consider trying other options first. I got off adderall, was tired for daysss, learned more about ADHD & more about myself.. & I don't have it all figured out but I feel alive & unaltered & like myself & EVERYONE can tell when the real me is showing.. having people who understand & love me the way I helps me want to care for myself better by eating better, sleeping earlier, exercising & relaxing more, & being alone, without distractions when I study. Be easy with yourself, DO NOT GIVE UP, you ARE NOT alone!

column2: 19-24 Female  (Patient)
column9: I feel like many doctors are prescribing far to high of a dosage of this medication to start. I am currently prescribed 30mg/day in 10mg tablets. column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking Adderall XR a year ago, w/o a prescription.  I am in my last year of college and up until last year, I could never pay attention in class or study.  I started taking 20mg when I had to study, and instantly my grades improved.  I now take it whenever I have class to attend or when I am studying, which is between 2-4 times a week.    I start to feel it about 30-60 mins after I take it. If I'm tired, it wakes me up completely(I am never tired during its duration). It lasts about a total of 6 hours for me (female, 110 pounds).During these hours, I only desire to study and learn. In class, I am now very attentive and class goes by so much quicker for me.  In the past, I just daydream and can't stand sitting there for more than 1.5 hours.  Now, I can sit through a 5 hour class.  I also participate a lot in class now, it makes me want to show everyone how smart I am, haha.  However, when I am on it, I do not like people talking to me because all I want to do is study. People now always tell me how much of a nerd I am, which makes me feel really happy :)Side effects: dry mouth, my old O.C.D. tendencies spring up, I do not eat (I lose weight during the part of the week that I take it), I smoke cigarettes (I recently quit and never desire one, but when I take adderall, I smoke a lot), I cannot sleep until 5am even if I take it at 8am.I do notice that I build a tolerance to it whenever I take it like three days in a row.  It doesn't last as long.Basically, during those 6 hours, all I want to do is study.  I'd imagine that if I took it on a day where I had no studying/class, I'd probably go NUTS.  I guess because I am normally focused in everything else, just not in schoolwork.It has definitely helped me (my GPA is now 3.6, compared to 2.0 before taking it) and I do not crave it on the days that I don't take it. However, I can definitely see how detrimental the side affects of this drug can be, and I'm so glad I only have one more year of school left!

column2: rmn, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am 41 years old, and have had the worst life ever, ever since I was younger, I have made millions of mistakes, many bad decisions, dropped out of school, never finished or accomplished anything, never got a degree, and now work as a waitress with 6 children to support, that 3 of the 6 all have different fathers. I have been on this medication for 3 months now, and what a complete turnaround, talk about 360! I can focus more on important things, I even noticed a change in my driving, instead of running around like a chicken with its head cut off, I have slowed down and started enjoying things, and am much better at dealing with with problems instead of running away from them, I have also been writing a journal everyday, and remembering things alot better, and feel I am thinking before I open my mouth first. the only problem I have noticed lately, is that at night, I get a little edgy. other than that I love the fact that I feel like I am finally in control of all the racing things that used to go on in my head, and now I can sit back and relax for a change, and organize my priorities, whereas before I could not.

column2: Photographer, 35-44 on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years
column9: I am a successful nationally known professional advertising photographer who was on Adderall for about five years and then decided that I did not need it anymore because all of my old ADHD habits where mostly gone. I was off of them for about three months and all of those long gone adhd habits that had played havoc with my life started coming back one by one. Unpaid parking tickets, loosing my keys, rash decisions, unfinished project after unfinished project. Within six months I had almost lost my photography business that I had worked so hard for and had collections agencies after me etc.  Wow what a bust to my ego! I guess I really do need to be on Adderall. It's as if when I am not on Adderall I know exactly what it is I need to do to keep my life running smooth...I put together my to do list but the to do list never gets completed. Yes I am a successful advertising photographer with lots of talent...but without the discipline and focus to apply that talent my world falls apart. I guess I just need to take it...it is what it is. I know there are lots of talented artists who take adderall...and I do not feel it makes me any less creative....or for that matter any more creative. How one little adderall XR pill makes the difference between being reasonably disciplined and totally irresponsible, however, is beyond me...but for me the reality is just that. I am now back on Adderall 20 MG XR and things are going great again. Hope this was helpful to any other artists out there who are struggling with the to medicate/not to medicate question. In my case the choice was made for me...I do not even think I would still be in business without this drug..no kidding.

column2: none, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: it did a good job calming me down and letting me really focus.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have had ADHD, most likely since I was a young kid (I'm now 24), but diagnosed a little over 1 year ago.  I recently finished graduate school, and stopped the Adderall since I stopped seeing the MD.  Now that I've been back on it (about 2 weeks) I'm much more focused, I don't drift off when I'm speaking to clients and feel more motivated to finish my work on time.  I'm also  not binging as often as I used to, which is extremely helpful since I have gained 10 pounds in the last 6 months.  I don't feel aggressive or angry to the point where its affecting my life and hurting others.  Of course, I still have to make some behavioral changes to improve my organizational skills, but that's not something any medication can fix.  Don't expect it to change everything, as part of the treatment for ADHD is to learn new tools to combat the symptoms.  This medication is not a good idea if you or any family members have a history of substance abuse or dependence, since you are predisposed to those conditions.  If you have any psychiatric issues in addition to the ADHD, you must speak with your doctor about them, since treatment will be counterproductive.  You play the greatest role in your treatment-not the medication.

column9: I was diagnosed with ADD in the third grade and was part of a national study (I Later learned) researching Rittalin<----(Spell Check). I am now looking at graduating college in December and was prescribed Adderall at the beginning of this semester. I have been a stellar student this semester and have accomplished more in one semester than I have in my entire collegiate career. I echo some of the previous posts regarding the problem with jitters and increases in tobacco use. I am not a a doctor and in no way am I posing as one on this blog. However,  i would recommend if you are seeing an increase in your tobacco habits try using hard candies to suck on when you have the urge to smoke your 4th cigarette in a row, this helped me reduce my urges and aided the hand to mouth habit that is associated with many smokers. Again, this may or may not help you at all and if you are concerned you should inform for doctor immediatly.
