fashiongirl, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with borderline narcolepsy, CFS, and fibromyalgia as a young teenager.  I have taken many things to keep me awake-uncluding provigil and ritalin.  Provigil helped, but I was still tired all of the time and would still fall asleep at the drop of a hat.  I have been taking adderall 20mg 2x a day for only a short time.  It has made a big difference so far.  I am always very careful with medications, so I am very nervous about the long term effects.  When I take adderall, I do not want to eat for 3-4 hours after, so I have not been eating breakfast or lunch.  My boyfriend and my mom (the closest people to me) have noticed a change in me.  I can make decisions easily (never used to be able to do this) and I am not as emotional.  It has helped me to stay awake, focus, and live like someone without sleep disorders, so for the time being-I am very happy.

column2: schwartzb17@gmail.com, 13-18 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I began taking adderall at 15mg when I was in the 4th grade (2001-2002) I lost about 28 pounds almost immediatly which was not a bad thing because I was about 30 pounds over weight. My doctor moved me down to 12 mg to stop the weight lose, which it did. I did however notice that it was not working as well so I was placed back onto 15 mg. The 15 mg dosage no longer worked as well as it originally did so I was bumped up to 20 mg and than once again to 25mg and in the 8th grade I was finally bumped up to 30mg where I remain to this day in the 11th grade.Side effects I have experienced:Lose of WeightLose of ApetiteDepressionO.C.D symptoms (extermely prevelent in my last two years)AnxietyParanoiaP.T.S.DIt is strange I go through a living hell almost day by day which may or may not be because of the Adderall but I can not just stop taking it because I fear being the way I am when I'm off of it during my everyday life because I get really "crazy" when I am not on it and eat a lot and just am moody and its pretty bad so I stay on it even though sometimes (more than less) I feel like a am losing my mind. I sometimes wonder what I would be like today if 8 years ago I had not been put on Adderall. (I actually did not have ADHD in the beginning it was ADD but it seemed to have developed into ADHD.)

column2: Nein, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have mild-moderate ADD, but without the hyperactivity. I have been on and off adderall, and usually on very small dosages.  It usually helps, but unfortunately I get side effects pretty bad from stimulant drugs.  The jittery feeling, increased hear rate, and loss of appetite.  The jitters were the worst.  I could focus my mind but I still felt squirmy and totally "out of it."  Sometimes, I was TOO focused, and could only concentrate on what was going on in my head, and felt out of touch with the outside world.  As far as concentration for school goes, it was very helpful, but my doctor took me off it because he was worried about my health.  I tried the XR once, but did not like it as much because it took too long to work and was not as strong.  no other drug seems to have been as helpful.

column2: dominoK, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am a 48 y.o university professor,  - after years of frustration and depression because of my procrastination habits and, as I described it, a lack of engagement between my brain and my body. I finally went into therapy just over a year ago at the urging of my wife and was diagnosed with ADHD. I started taking Adderall about 8 months ago. I have found that Adderall is very effective at helping me to focus and listen. It helps me to be more deliberate in my actions, I'm not just drifting through the day. In my classroom I have found that I am able to listen to myself better and not be distracted by those students who give me that 'I'm so bored' look. One of the most interesting effects I've found is that I now actually hear and listen to the lyrics of songs! - never did that before. Looking back at my life, all the way to when I was 6 years old I now recognize the symptoms that had always been there.  I feel that the treatment is working for me, but as my doctor says, the worst part is that I'm 48 and have only now finally taken care of a life-long problem. I take 30 mg. (15 mg standard 2 x a day). I did feel the side effects for about the first two or three days (teeth grinding and dry mouth) but they subsided and I don't have any issues with that now. I've lost a few pounds, but I love to eat and  once I start eating, my appetite is fine. I know that I'll have to continue with this, probably for the rest of my life, but I think of it as a simple compound that my body chemistry is simply missing - so it helps me a lot.Finally I would say to those of you suffering horrible side effects, stop, and get another opinion! If the side effects are that bad, then you probably have a different problem. Amphetamines are an important drug that can work well for those who need it, but if you don't, you are abusing it. I thought that it would be like the speed we experimented with in high school, but it's not. It is an essential part of my life now, stigma or not -

column2: jb, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I've been taking Adderall for the past 3 months. I switched over from Focalin because that drug did little to improve my ADD; it just made me irritable once it wore off. I'm on 30 mg twice a day now. The drug puts me in a good place but it doesn't seem to accomplish its actual purpose. I know I've become dependent on it even in this short period of time. Other users have noted this drug should be avoided if you have an addictive personality. I agree completely. It never occured to me that I might have ADD,I was more concerned about my depression. Anyways, my psych noted that I consume about three caffinated drinks a day along with a pack and a half of cigarettes. Now this drug is just another one of the stimulants I consume throughout the day to feel normal, or at least like what I have come to consider "normal." Seriously, I've met herion addicts who expressed concern when I told them I take Adderall. This drug is dangerous. Part of me thinks the companies behind it are guilty of endangering a lot of people, but when I remember how I felt just after a few days of being off it, you won't see me trying to stop them.

column2: DevinT, 19-24 on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: In high school, my mom kept on me to do my schoolwork, which was good.  However, half way through college, I started failing classes not having support, so I went to the school counselor.She helped me out a bit with a schedule, but still in crunch time, halfway through a Term (quarter), I just couldn't focus for homework.  She brought up ADD, so I contacted a Psychiatrist.My psychiatrist wasn't there, so I had my initial assessment with a stand in.  She said I probably have Bipolar II (hypomanic-depressive).  Shocked, I still geared up and looked up symptoms and this and that.  Sure, so I have mild/moderate Bipolar...I thought everyone did.I had an appointment with my real psychiatrist, and he was on the edge on if I was Bipolar or ADD.  Apparently, a lot of the symptoms overlap.  It was possible I have both, though, so I scheduled another appointment and took Lamictal for BP2.The appointment after that was halfway through the term.  The mood swings were better, but I still couldn't focus.  I was "driven to distraction" as he put it.  I would procrastinate to the point where I was not confident I could get the work done, and then to cheer myself up, I would do the very thing that I used to procrastinate (like a video game).He prescribed me this stuff, Amphetamine Salts.  I took it the day after he prescribed it...and for good reason.  I had an assignment due the next morning.  I had a meeting to prepare for and run.  I had important people to email.It felt like I was sipping on a heavily caffeinated beverage all day.  That's when I'm most motivated.  I got all the emails sent out, I ran the meeting just fine, and I edited 8 pages of a document that I have been sitting on for over a year.The side effects I experienced were dry mouth, muscle tension, strange busts of tiredness that go away in 10 minutes, high blood pressure (expected), feeling a little cold, easy smiling, and restlessness.It's been 3 days.  I actually WANT to do work now.  So weird...

column2: Success from St. Louis, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Adderall for six years now and what a difference it has made in my life.  I was finally diagnosed w/ADD when I was 20.  All my life I STRUGGLED through school (constantly daydreaming, forgetting assignments, awful  comprehension). I studied so hard and still earned mostly Cs. Teachers suggested to my parents that I be tested for ADD but I refused because I thought it meant I was dumb.  When I went away to college I did not have my parents reminding me to study or do homework.  The work load and subject matter was increasingly more difficult until one semester I ended up with a 1.5 GPA.  At that point I had enough of the struggle and I made an appointment with my Doctor.  After going through testing I was diagnosed with ADD and was put on Adderall.  I suddenly started to really enjoy school and on top of it all, I really wasn't dumb.  I ended that semester with a 3.85 GPA.  I got an A in Quantitative Business Statistics and loved the class. I continued on with excellent grades and enjoying school and graduated from a State University with a Bachelor of Science.  My only regret is not starting this treatment sooner.  I think that years of struggling through school, feeling left behind, and feeling "stupid" has a negative impact on a child's development of self confidence, self esteem, and perseverance in life. For people that are "on the fence" about taking medication or allowing their child to take meds to treat truly DIAGNOSED ADD/ADHD, ask yourself this..... If(you/your child) had diabetes would you not give your(self/child) insulin?  Everyone should have all the tools they need to succeed.  I am thrilled to be succeeding in life!!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
Amythyst, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: For years I struggled with ADD and when I was in 10th grade I was put on ritalin...I hated it...I also have a social phobia and a anxiety disorder that causes panic attacks, I also had suffered from depression and Insomnia for many years...My pychiatrist put me on 10 mg in 2000 to start out with...Started out working great...However, Paranoia doesn't help the effect....I am a very petite woman with a high metabolism...I took adderall until 2002 due to a nervous breakdown and loss of too much weight...In 2002, I weighed 68 lbs...I was taken off of it immediately and was put on seroquel...I was on Straterra since 2003 I believe and it worked good for a while...But, I wasn't getting anything done...I am back on adderall and really watching my weight this time...I no longer suffer from depression but, I do still have a social phobia...Adderall helps this alot...Also, I am able to get things done...It's a very caustious drug...You have to be extremely careful taking it...:)

column2: dd, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I am a mental health therapist, and reading these reviews of Adderall makes me want to laugh and cry at the same time.  I am also taking adderall, and know in my heart that I am addicted, and struggle with knowing this everyday.  With not wanting to refill my script, but knowing that the addict in me will call my doctor and get a refill.  Knowing that I will become emotionless and cold, sleepless and edgy, but with a clean house and unhappy children who don't understand why their mom is so tense and angry.  I know that I will start having to take Zanax and Ambien to calm down at night, and that the divide between my husband and I will grow bigger.  This medication helped me at first, it felt like legal meth.  Because that is what it is.  The sad thing is, I was working in the substance abuse field when I began by adderall journey.  I am not saying that everyone will experience what I am going through, but my sister also has the exact same problems.  While I thought we would be having cookouts and taking our kids to the park, instead we are swapping scripts and pills and cleaning tips.  I caution everyone who is thinking about taking this drug to consider whether they can do it responsibly, and their family history of addiction.  Reading these other reviews makes me feel much less alone, but also very sad that so many people are having these problems.  I realize that I may need help to get off of it, but that is very hard when you work in the field that I do and your professional reputation is on the line.  I use up my script in less than two weeks, and then have two weeks without it.  The two weeks w/out it are so much better, but the addict in me never listens.  Every month I think I can do it responsibly.  I just wonder, when is it gonna be to much?  I know the saying one is to many and a thousand is never enough.  In my case, that is so true.  Please be careful.

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I did not have A.D.D or adhd,but was diagnosed with Depression and severe anxiety.I have been thru countless anti- depressants.Wellbutrin was ok.But something still felt like it was missing.    I have a "Mentally challenged" friend who has adhd or a.d.d and he had a prescription of Adderall.Since I was a stupid young teen,I loved experimenting with pills I had no prescription to.After the first pill I felt on top of the world.I could speak better/faster/more intelligent.I could focuse better,I had NO ANXIETY what so ever of any sort.I had REALLY bad social anxiety and fears of situations before they even happend.But with Adderal,it disapeared 110%.In fact with Adderall,I WANTED! to go out and socialize,when usually I would just hide in my room for days/weeks/months((no joke))so finally I got my own perscription.The doctor wasnt sure about it,but I told him about all the countless benifits I was having,and he finally let me have it.    Of course there was a downside to this to though =(  Eventually,I started to abuse it.Taking it more often than I should have.I would even chop it up and let it dissolve in water.Stay up all night & pull all nighters (which was still kinda fun,,I got to wright some of my best guitar riffs back then and clean my room spic and span)) but I got real irritable when taking tooo much.OMG and the TEETH GRINDING LOL!!!!Another thing I disliked about being on close to slightly over amount is my penis would shrink greatly lol.Though I could still "get it up" when needed.It looks like I came out of cold pool.    Anyway,,,,I really miss this pill,almost 10 years have past,I'd like to give it another try but be a little more responsible this time.

column2: mylifearemyboys4, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been switching between Adderall XR and Adderall non-time released for about 3 years. Right now I take 90 milligrams a day of Adderall non-time released. I have days where I am tired, on these days I take more than perscribed. In my opinion Adderall is highly "abusive". When you take a medication long enough your body becomes immune and the medication isnt as effective as it was when you first started taking it.I dont think Adderall should be prescribed to children under the age of 18. All it takes is a simple 20 question evaluation and you are prescribed a drug that may forever change your life. I have tried to stop taking Adderall and I have not been successful yet. I get so mad at myself when I sleep for 5 days straight (when im finally back to normal) and then go back to the Adderall.My advice to anyone condsidering this medication is to get a second opinion. Honestly, I know I dont have ADHD or ADD, the Adderall makes me have ADHD. I didnt need this medication when I was prescribed it 3 years ago and now I cant get away from it. I have faith in God that He will get me through this and allow me to feel again. The Will of God will never take you where the grace of God cannot protect you. God bless you all!!

column2: Truth (Patient)
column9: I believe I have a mix of hyperactivity and inattentivness.. I'm easily distracted, like to be on the move (as if driven by a motor), its hard to stay on task, I zone-out/daydream here & there, I find it hard to be motivated, especially in school (unless I am genuinely interested in the material & feel it really applies to my life). I procrastinate, can be quite disorganized, and stress out because of this all! Thats when I dont take Adderall.  Only somewhat effective because the tablets tend to wear off as the day progresses which results in irritability, they initially get me down to business. I'd hoped that side-effecrs wouldnt apply to be but well in reality they do. this drug really is no joke and should be taken seriously because of its habit-forming tendency. i dont like the idea of depending on a substance to do things i used to be able to do without it. true, those things were harder to do before Adderall, but: when i would go a day or 2 without it, or just be on a lower dose, i found that the fatigue that set in as a result (side-effect) made those things harder than it had been before ever taking the Adderall! Essentially Adderall had picked me & dropped me lower than before =/ I don't want to go back off of it, however i do want my genuine self back, the one that isn't so serious and annoyed. high blood pressure is another thing to look out for. this can raise it. it makes me tense at times. But if you're like me you'll like it AT FIRST. It helps me work & i mean efficiently, but I don't always need this stuff.. maybe when i have a paper due but not when just hanging with friends. i made it without Adderall but it wasnt easy & it especially isnt now that i've been on it. Learning about ADD helps me understand myself better & discover under what conditions i'm best able to work. this'll make a difference in whether I decide to continue it. I of course respect that the severity of the ADD in any case also must be addressed. Dosage is also very important.

column9: I suffer from chronic fatigue.  After trying several different meds, this one is the only one that has made a difference in my ability to wake up and get going.  A big difference.  I take 40 mgs when I get up and sometimes another 20 in the afternoon.  It has made my life so much better.  It is not perfect, but I'd rather take it than feel like I did before.  When my new Dr. said she wouldn't be able to prescribe it, I cried.  My quality of life was at stake.  I changed doctors.

column9: excellent medication for my hadhd i use to be  scattered, unorganized,.. ect now i work effective and sleep easily

column2: CollegeStudent, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am a 23 year old college student.  I started taking adderall to help me with my school work about 7 months ago.  Before the medicine I procrastinated, could not finish a projects, was disinterested, and unmotivated.  When I take this medication I shed all of those characteristics. I am able to study for about 5-8 hours straight and obtain all the information. I am in my senior year of college and thought I could use a push to finish the hard classes. I became interested in learning; I grasped concepts easily, and became level headed and rational.  I will say though, there is a huge downside.  I got bad headaches, lost ten pounds, blacked out frequently for a second when I stood up, chest pains, and numbness in my hands. When on the medication, I lost my connection to emotion and was very irritable.  I tended to be cold and distant.  I know this medicine works but I did not want to put my body through the side effects any longer.I have stopped taking this due to the person I was becoming.  It takes more discipline for me to study and stay focused but at least I feel like my true self. This drug is habit forming. I thought I could not get an A on a test without it, but I did and I can.  Plus now when I get an A it is more rewarding knowing it was all me who earned, not the adderall.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Freshman yr of college i was diagnosed with ADD, the Inattentive kind. My experience with Adderall has been a love/hate relationship. I started on 20mg in a.m. & 10mg in p.m. It gave me more energy, made me mentally sharper & I felt normal & happier since I was more able to communicate & think clearly. I was happy.. at first. Then I noticed I could stay up WAY late. Then I'd sleep in & miss the classes I'd finally begun thoroughly doing the work for. Also, friends pointed out Id become irritable & mean at times. I agreed but was upset because of all the good adderall was doing for me otherwise. The tablets wore off later in the day, causing my moods. My prescriber recommended a higher dose, I agreed & I liked it, I was focused on getting my stuff done. STILL, I was.. cold, emotions were distant. IMPORTANT: check before you start this if theres a history of addictions to substances like alchohol etc in your family as this can really be HABIT-FORMING, as in my case. Also, Adderall doesnt allow refills. This was prob when back from out of state college & I had insurance- coverage issues, which forced me to go off adderall. DIFFICULT. I was SO tired, moreso than EVER before. felt like a moody addict & sad & like doing NOTHING.2nd day with no Adderall in my system, woke up during the night & threw up. Horrible & bizarre. BE CAREFUL, listen to your body's signs if on it. Try keeping lowest dose possible. Off adderall, I still had a job to get & chores ETC when just functioning was a task. Gained back the weight i'd lost, plus a few. After that I felt better each day, but back to my spacey, scattered & anxious self again. Caffiene helped, in big amts. Insurance is fixed, I caved & am back on it. They say you'll feel like a different person. Maybe, I feel my old Adderall self returning, more focused but mean. My family has noticed. Mom said i'm not my old self. & I fear I'm becoming dependent again. Im taking lower doses & may switch to Dexedrine or Adderall XR. Think.

column2: lp2u2, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Adderall now for 2.5 years. I am also on Zoloft & Lamictal. I have noticed an increase in anger and rage over the last 2 years or so, and I have been researching ALL of these drugs in order to find out if all 3 are causing these highly charged emotions, or just one or two. The smallest incident can absolutely en-rage me to the point of screaming and then crying out of frustration or just plain anger. I'm wondering if anyone else has these issues with adderall, in particular. I am not even sure I could function without this drug, but I want off ALL of them and I need to taper myself off them. I know my liver is damaged from them, and I fear with the anger I have inside me, someone will get hurt or someone will hurt me. Another issue for me is that these drugs aren't manufactured in the United States, and the big Pharmaceuticals contract with China & India which aren't quality controlled. This actually makes me VERY angry, so I am going to get off these and try to be normal, and IF I still have these destructive emotions when I'm off them, then I must seek help elsewhere. Adderall in my opinion is a very dangerous drug and giving any ADD drug to a child, adolescent or adult is irresponsible and the drug companies do NOT give a hoot about people, as it is ALL about PROFIT. The FDA is just as corrupt as the big Pharma, and together they are in collusion and both have made billions on people's lives and deaths.Research it yourself and open your eyes to the corruption in our country, including our own government in regard to the big Pharma's and the FDA. It will scare the HELL out of you!!!

column2: grj1983, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: It's a restricted prescription, just like narcotics. It's hard for me to obtain,but if I don't,I do bad things. I hit someone head on in my car, for ex. I think taking this drug for 10 years (since age 15 or 16 or so), has also had me turn into a raging psychopath when I'm coming off it. It only gets worse. I don't know I am acting badly, other people who know me complain. I think it's impossible to fix ADD or ADHD, because... why is it such a problem to not be able to sit still? Isn't everyone fat these days because they are far too lazy? Seems dumb to try to fix people who are hyper or not attentive. The world is a boring place. School is boring too. While this substance improved my grades during school, I found no satisfaction in my life. It numbs my feelings. It makes me more agressive and mean. But as far as helping ADD or ADHD, I don't think it does that at all anymore. My thoughts still race, I still get distracted, I am still bouncing with energy. I am on 90mg a day. Thats as high as it gets. Even though it doesn't help, I take it because I am afraid I will hurt someone else if I stop. I do not know who I am without this medication. People who take it to feel less tired are abusing it. People who give it to kids SHOULD NOT. People who take it to be less depressed are abusing it. It's not for depression. I'd reccomend exersize for that (not a doc). Besides all that, I'm tired of having to spend my time chasing after this drug every month to fill up on my prescription, because some people think it's cool to take it recreationally. THAT is the dumbest thing of all. This is the least fun drug, ever. They should adjust it so there is no more false euphoria from this drug in anyone. I never felt euphoria of any kind from it. But to give it to a kid that DOES (even legally), I could see it as being addictive. I've been medicated since I was 5, Ritilan, countless anti-depressants and then back to the desoxyn and Adderall.Yeah-I don't even talk to my parents anymore.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: For Adult ADD - I've just had issues with getting the ideal dosing schedule with this. Has made me stop taking my SSRI, and feel like I accomplish things. Was taking 20mg XR once daily, then twice daily, but due to price, went to plain. Seems to work longer than XR. column2: Taximan, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was given 15 mg a day of this for my chronic exhaustion. However, I quickly realized that it has made my depression go away. The problem is I need about 40 - 60 mg to get rid of the depression. My pdoc won't give me that much, and so I remain depressed. I don't know what to do because nothing makes my depression go away like Adderall does. I also find it's not necessary to take it everyday. I find it best to skip every 3rd day so I can sleep. It does cause insomnia, but I had that before I ever took Adderall. This is like a miracle drug for me. Now if only I knew a doc who would give me enough to last all month.

column2: raven688, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Works for me!

column2: brett, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm 20 and in my first year of college. I was diagnosed with ADD in 6th Grade for my lack of ability to concentrate, I was/am quite the day dreamer. The Doc put me on 5mg Adderall XR I believe. My freshman year the dose was increased to 10mg. At the time I didn't know fully how it effected me, all I knew is that it made me want to throw desks at the teachers that irritated me, and that I was unhappy and pissed of for no reason. I switched from adderall to stratera, then to ritali LA, but I prefered not taking anything because of how they effected me. In January I started back on Adderal XR @ 15mg and I told myself that it's worth the sacrifice to have good grades and be able to focus, but I  now that I am older I am more aware of how it effects me. My grades immediately went from C's to high B's and the Highest gpa I've had in years. I quit taking it when I realized that it was destroying my life in the following ways:-Extreme OCD behavior-Depression-AntiSocial behavior-Muscular twitches-Dependence-Most of all, Loss of identityNaturally I am a outgoing person, I love people, I'm easy going, and always have a smile on my face but Adderall flipped my world upside down. I would not recommend any parent putting their child on this medication under any circumstance, if you care about them at all. ADD is not a disorder, it is just a way to classify people who function on a higher/different level than the average population. ADD is a gift that our society hasn't learned how to handle. My recommendation to parents would be to look for and encourage the abilities and gifts your child has, and be as supportive as you possibly can. They need to know that they are brilliant, creative, and gifted. The reason ADD'ers can't focus well is because they are constantly thinking! What kind of world do we live in when thinking needs to be medicated?!

column2: brightdreamer, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was taking this for ADD without hyperactivity. It seemed to help at first, I was concentrating better, keeping up with tasks, and getting more things done. However, I'm also being treated for depression, and after only a few weeks I started noticing the symptoms of my depression coming back. After a full month on the drug, I was extremely irritable, overreacting to stress, crying at every little thing, snapping at friends and family... I really damaged a relationship with one friend, sadly. Upon talking to my doctor, I found out that Adderall can cause heightened emotions, which is exactly what I was trying to treat with the depression medication! She offered to put me on a mood stabilizer drug as well, but I said just take me off the Adderall and try something else for the ADD rather than adding another drug to fix its side effects. I'm trying Strattera now, we'll see how it works. The drug did what it was supposed to do, but honestly, my ADD isn't bad enough to warrant taking a drug with this kind of side effect.

column2: bhytc43, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I first saw a doctor when I was 17 yrs. old seeking treatment for depression and constant lethargy. However, after answering a short questionnaire, I was diagnosed with ADD, and have been on Adderall (which was helpful at first) ever since. Now, I've been on the medication so long that I can't remember who, or how I was before I started taking it. In addition to causing my mild OCD to become full blown routine-altering OCD, I find that the medication increases my irritability 10 fold (especially when it's wearing off, and especially within the last year). I'm not sure if it is the medication or simply life circumstances that is now causing me severe depression, extreme lack of motivation, and weird and very sudden mood swings. I have also experienced more common side effects, like jaw clenching, tension, dizziness, and increased heart rate. I would like to try to stop taking the medication now, but feel I am dependent on it and am afraid of the withdrawal effects. I worry about the long term side effects that I may experience from taking this drug for so long, and the misery that it may/may not be causing me presently. I would NEVER consider putting a child on this medication.

column2: Cat-mom, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have taken a low dose of adderall for about five years, and it has changed my life. My ability to think ahead, anticipate and avoid problems has dramatically improved. My abilty to articulate myself improves dramatically on adderal  especially with a low dose.  I can understand the consequences of my actions with a clarity that I wish I had earlier in life J My over-all attention span has dramatically improved in the last five years  and it remains significantly higher even on days when I choose not to take adderall. To me, that is amazing. Tasks I once found painful, I can now do quickly an efficiently with patience and perfect detail  even off adderall. A large part of why I think I see a lot of improvement is not just the medication, but also all the other things I do to combat ADHD.When I need to learn something new (e.g. a software program at work) adderal helps me quickly learn and absorb the new information, and remember facts. It is a dramatic change from my past abilities.When I first started taking the drug, I had heart palpitations. It is definitely hard on the heart. BUT then I started to add regular, gentle but rigorous aerobic exercise to my routine (which, btw, is a non-prescription treatment for ADHD), my heart became stronger, more conditioned than before and the palpitations stopped. My resting hr is 45 bpm, and my blood pressure is ideal, or close to it. This also will solve any insomnia problems.I recommend this drug  FOR THE RIGHT PERSON. Fact is we are all built differently. Which is the whole reason why drugs like this are made in the first place. Depending on your peculiarities, it may not give you exactly what you need.  That doesnt mean this drug wont be very helpful to someone else. I look forward to the day when these types of drugs can be prescribed and monitored more accurately.

column2: wendycordes@yahoo.com, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Caregiver)
column9: i as a mom of 4kid's two with adhd i feel that they should take this drug off the drug market i'm very angree that they can use this medication when the side effects out weigh it's self they call this medication safe i call it child endarangerment it is killing my 10yr.old son he has bleeding comming from nose and now in his mouth what the heck kinda medication is this taking live's

column2: c_jernigan, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: My initial response to Adderall XR was great - it changed my life, but then ... and there is always a "but" in life - the effects began to wear off and then I think that Adderall began muting my endocrine system.  In a nutshell - it significantly reduced my level of perceived anxiety. I didn't realize it, but I was probably living with a "4" on a 1 - 10 scale for general anxiety.  Adderall brought me down to a 1 or 2.  I think that basically after a month or two my adrenaline and other things were basically either all used up, or the receptor sites were burned out.  Basically there was no "fire" because all of the fuel had been burned up.  Also, I think that I had some mild depression creeping in - I became somewhat unmotivated, and really didn't want to do much physically.After about 1 year my libido dropped like a rock, my testicles felt as if they had shrunken to 1/2 their normal size.  My body temperature was always low - it was routinely in the mid 96 to low 97 range.  I had no physical strength nor endurance - where I had been previously in good shape and could crank out 25 pushups at any given time, I could only manage 20 or so "girl" pushups (supported by knees) after which time I was exhausted.  After working out, I didn't feel as if I was gaining any benefit or very minor benefit, almost as if I was having a muted recovery.  After initially becoming more organized I began slipping back, then I was maybe only 25% of my initial organization. I have stopped taking XR on a daily basis and have begun taking it only "as needed" - what my doctor doesn't know will not hurt him.  I think that something needs to be recharged - I am now an advocate of "drug holidays", every other day usage, or simply "as needed" be that at work, or home. I never found myself feeling mentally addicted - but I did have brain fog for a couple of days when stepping down.I was on 30mg/day Adderall XR - 40yo male - ~18 months.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been taking the XR 20mg a day for about 6 months now and it has completely changed my life. You would have never known I had an attention problem because I was a very active teenager.  I was involved in sports, many extracuricular activities and worked since I was 16 so my mind was constantly focused on something different.  It became a problem after becoming a single mom.  I couldn't organize any thought.  If there was too much going on I couldn't focus to organize it.  I didn't pay bills, I took extreme chances, and even forgot I was a mom sometimes.  After finally confessing to my mother how i felt she suggested talking to my PCP.  He gave me the 20mg XR 6 months ago and now I feel as though I am actually living my life.  I have since fixed my finances, gotten promoted at work, and enjoy my time with my daughter so much more.  I would suggest this treament to anyone as long as their Dr. agrees.  Use caution when taking this it can be very addicting, and should not for children that have no gone through puberty.  i have lost 30 pounds since start because of the lack of appetite and amount of exercise i do.  I also have about two nights a week that i have trouble falling asleep.  over all I thank myself every day for being able to communicate how I felt.  I am finally the person I always wanted to be and never thought could be.

column2: Ben, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Started taking Adderall 5 years ago and it has worked incredibly well. Until the early evening I have very little appetite but if I decide I have to eat, it's not difficult and generally my appetite returns a bit once i start eating. I feel totally able to pay attention to my work, writing papers, reading textbooks, focusing in lectures which was impossible before Adderall or when I miss a dose. I took Ritalin for several months before switching to Adderall with no effect at all.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have always struggled in school and my parents did not believe in ADD or ADHD.  I would listen to someone talk to me for 10 minutes and not be able to tell you one word that they said. column2: Miss Bonner, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been diagnosed with bipolar disorder along with PTSD since I was thirteen. I am now 25, and I decided to try this medication perscribed by my new psychiatrist; who has rediagnosed me with ADHD.  During the first day of two 30mg. tablets I did fine, with the exception of a few jitters.  I wasn't sleepy or depressed as usual.  After consulting my doctor, he said it was a sign that I should double my dosage.  Then came the second and third days.  I was a maniac!  I would sit for hours preforming illogical tasks that I couldn't stop; like combing my hair for 6 hours.  My eyes were dialated, I ached from being tense, and I also felt disconnected from the world.  I was very irritable, paranoid, dizzy, sweating, short of breath, and OCD.  I couldn't fall asleep without prescription medications.  I was too anxious to even take the trash out.  I will never take stimulants of this kind again.  Afterall, I know I am bipolor, but the thought of removing that diagnosis gained enough of my trust to try stimulants.  I've never felt more crazy!  The days just flew by and I have no idea what I did.  Needless to say, I'm looking for a new doctor.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)

I've tried lowering the dose as well as raising it but still experience the same sypmtoms. I will be fine taking it if I havent had it in a few days but the come down is so terrible that I am unable to sleep properly for the next 2 days and experience a hangover so terrible that I am unable to take it again for at least 3 days. It did help me concentrate but makes me extremely antisocial and fearful of speaking in a classroom or out in public. I was not like this before I started taking it. I also have been getting terrible panic attacks so bad that I need to lay down and force myself to sleep until it passes. column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with ADD about 8 mnonths ago and am prescribed to Adderall 20mg 2x a day. I talked to my doctor about it after I got an office job. Knowing how much better I could have done in high school if I had been prescribed to it then really makes me wonder how much more I could have accomplished as far as scholarships and things of that nature. Overall, taken responsibly adderall has been 100% effective. The biggest side effect I'v experienced has been a lack of hunger. I've lost probably 20 pounds in the last 8 months. column2: addledinindiana, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Adult ADDer diagnosed at 5 yrs 'hyperkinetic:' prescr barbituates. At 9, diff doc prescr Dexedrine: huge improvement. Family moved: no dr, no meds. 'til school insisted I be treated. New doc prescr Dexedrine. Life again improved significantly. Another family move: no meds, no dr.  Impulse took hold: I ran away & got married. New OB/GYN precr Obetrol (Adderall) & amphetamine for ADHD/extreme impulsivity. I felt normal again. First son was a Rit kid, diagnosed ADHD at 5 years. As an adult, my hyperactivity DECREASED, while other ADD symptoms INCREASED: inattentiveness, distractions, severe impulsivity, reckless behavior. I tried all the ADHD meds and methyphenidates do not work for me. On Dex Spansules & tabs 'til the '90s. Thanks to Dex, I finished HS/college and attained a career (which didn't last). In '92, p-doc took me from ADD meds to HIGH doses of SSRIs. Spun out-of-control for over a decade.  Moved to IN in '02. After a couple of incidents resulting from my ADD I stopped SSRIs. Dr refused to prescr ADD meds & said she didn't "believe" in ADHD. She wrote Provigil for "focus" and a CPAP machine for sleep disorder, neither did 'squat.' Hit rock-bottom 3 months ago & found a NP who prescribed Adderall XR 20 mg. It helped a TINY BIT. At my pleading, she raised XR to 30mg & added a 10 mg d-amp tab to be broken in half, 5 mg in AM with XR, 5 mg early to mid PM.Her concern is my age. Phys health is GOOD: no heart, liver, kidney, lung problems. Low BP all my life. Never smoked, rarely drink maybe glass of wine once a month. XR is slow-starting, so mornings are shot before I know it, then have severe sleepy period in mid-aft. XR kicks in again around 5PM but then I hyperfocus on all the wrong things until 10-11PM, when I binge & fidget until I go to sleep with xanax around 1AM.Here is my personal dx: I'm under-dosed. On Adderall XR, a minimum 60mg x 2 plus 10mg D-amp x 2.Preference is Dex Spans + 5mg Dex tabs x 3.XR's inconsistent & a rollercoaster ride.

column2: Hopeful Engineering, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am a 23 year old recent college graduate that has been taking Adderall Oral for the past 6 to 7 months.  I was not diagnosed with ADD/ADHD until the start of my treatment.  With this treatment I have noted some very distinct changes in my performance in college and now in my career.  I am a Mechanical Engineer in NC.  My focus at work seems to be increased but not over the top.  I finally feel that I can start a project and follow it through to the end.  Finishing the minute details that have plagued me in the past and that I have procrastinated with in the past.  I feel that Adderall oral is an effective treatment for my condition.  Although I strongly urge parents and students to take caution with using this treatment option.  I have noticed a weekly to bi-weekly occurrence of limited sleep for one to two nights.  This seems to typically happen on a Friday night and Sunday nights.  As this has continued I feel that there are some other treatments that I should attempt before settling on this one.  Also as I was diagnosed during my final semester of college with ADD/ADHD I noticed that I suddenly had more friends then the prior 5 years of college.  So parents, students in college with go to extreme measures to acquire Adderall from your child. This is also becoming an increasing concern for college campuses across the nation.  Like I said before, I believe, this medication should be taken consistently and you shouldn't miss many treatments.  Missing treatments has made me extremely groggy and lazy.  So caution to not taking it on the weekends.  I have noticed that when I continued treatment for 7 days a week I didn't have the haze, groggy and lazy feeling.  Also I reduce my dosage to half during the weekends. I hope this helps all in some manner.

I am willing to try anything, I just want to be normal again, I want to be able to play with my kids, I don't want to be cranky anymore. I want to live, I am to young to be this old. Can anyone help.

column9: MY son he can concentrate much better at school.The behavior improve.

column2: Fred, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I took this medication because of my ADD problems in high school. My doctor originally started me off with a drug that is almost exactly Ritalin. I started with it in freshman year due to my lowly grades and noticeable problems. I started using the ritalin like drug, but saw no satisfying results. It also seemed to be correlated with having sleeping problems, appetite loss, and depression. So i stopped using it. When i went to my doctor and told him about  it he seemed to realize that the ritalin wasn't causing the stress and other problems, but it was just the the troubles of freshman year. The drug and my problems weren't actually connected. My doctor prescribed adderall for me in my sophomore year, and i almost instantaneously saw the improvements, faster reaction time, less daydreaming, and i could keep my grades up and remember my work with ease. Luckily i had parents that trusted me enough to let me keep the medication in my own place(in my room) because i was ashamed at first to have to take something to make myself better. It was as if it kind of lifted a disability completely off of my shoulders. Ive taken it all the way through college and stopped when i graduated, i experienced no real withdrawal, I just had to make a smooth transition which my doctor helped me with greatly. If taken in the right doses and not obsessed about it seems to be a very good help for my future and self esteem.Just realize that what you see as depression and other related things could very well be the much more stressful and much more dangerous thing called high school.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: ADD-no hyperactivity...but that was the only option to choose..I've taken adderall when i was in high school and then went off the medication for about a year. During that year my grades went from A's and B's to C's or below. Its not that i wasn't a hard worker, i just couldn't concentrate on school work. Its a great medicine and works if used correctly. There are a few complications with it if you take 40 mg or higher for a long period of time (i.e-years) i have read that there is a possiblity of heart complications. But if you stay at a healthy dose and don't go overboard..it works. Also, adderall XR is great b/c you only have to take it once a day, instead of twice a day.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have to say that I was very weary of using a drug for my adult ADHD (inattentive type) but adderall really makes my life alot easier. Though adderall is not a "silver bullet" it greatly helped me reach my potential as a college student. In high school I went undiagnosed and subsequently untreated which resulted in my sub par grades. It wasnt until college when I talked to my pyschiatrist who throughly evaluated me and first tried me on Ritalin which made me extremely tired, then finally Adderall. Adderall and therapy have allowed me to stay focused and acheive more than I ever dreamed possible. I'm now on the deans list with a 4.0 in my senior year of college. I was also really lucky to not really have any side effects or withdrawl symptoms, although if I take it too late in the day I have a hard time falling asleep, but thats to be expected from an amphetimine.

column2: Persimmon, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: This drug seems less harsh than ritalin, but it still causes a down feeling as it wears off. Nonetheless, - perhaps 50%+ of the time Adderall has been quite helpful in getting me in focus and on track.That is a great benefit because I find myself restlessly pacing much of the time and unable to initiate or complete projects, Often I have felt too defeated to even hoppe to begin a project. I have lived with thisa painful condition for 20 years or more. When I do dfocus i can becaome very effective and creative. It has been a strained interior battle to find ways to establish a balance and a rhythm in daily life.I also take the antidepressant Cymbalta and often I also need to take Artivan.So, it is a frustrating story. Adderall is a great help when it helps, and yet i worry about dependence and also the apparent habituation.All medications for mood and behavior seem to offer complicated trade-offs requiring frequent self-evaluation and consultation with doctors and also with friends and family. Often I feel embarrassed that I seem to need these types of medicines, and yet is  clear that for me they are helpful and also problematic.

column2: Kevin, 13-18 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I've been on Adderall on & off over the past few years (off because of pregnancy/nursing).  I've tried 10mg/day in 2 doses and also 10mg/day in 1 XR (extended release) dose.  It has been incredibly helpful.  I get more done in 1 day than I used to in a week or more.  My husband doesn't come home to find me in the middle of 10 unfinished "projects".  The 2 major downsides for me are the addictiveness and the loss of appetite.  I am a mess if I don't take it, and I am naturally a very small person to begin with, so the loss of appetite can be a pretty serious problem.  Eating & maintaining a reasonable weight is a daily struggle, but at least now I can keep up with my responsibilities enough that I even have time to eat!
I've been taking adderal for 7 years and 3 years ago I would have reccomended it.  However, I am now addicted and would not reccomend it to anyone, unless it is heavily supervised.

column2: jeffindixon@hotmail.com, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I am a 35 year old male that has been taking Adderall for almost 2 years now. My symptoms did not include hyperactivity but rather the ability to stay focused on anything detailed for any length of time. Ex: Im an Internet Sales Manager at a car dealership. At the start of this career 2.5 years ago, I did not have the energy, patience, attention span to learn the intricates of computers/websites/email programs. Since, I rose to the top of my industry to level of Consulting dealerships on how to sell more cars from the internet.Had I been medicated in high school, believe I could've been able to excel much further in school and career at that time, not in my mid thirties.

The main problem with Adderall is that it is extremely addictive. I started taking it to help me get through classes and work. I loved that it killed my appetite. I thought I'd be able to take it in moderation, but I take it everyday now. I just feel like a happier person when I take it. But I've noticed that I am distant and easily annoyed if I take too much. Sometimes I feel that I'm on the verge of having a panic attack. If I take 15 MG a day and I eat I feel amazing. But its very easy to avoid eating and take 30 MG because you just get so much done. Im very nervous that I will become strongly addicted to the drug. Im also nervous that I will loose too much weight. Scary.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
Robert K, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Adderall has worked very well for me. My thought process is much more organized and my ability to stay focused on a conversation and tuned into the subject at hand has improved immensely.  I have over the years tried to slow and constrain my hyperactivity with lorasapam and other sedatives with only a moderate amount of success; major side effect was drossiness and fatigue. I looked into the possibilities of Adderall after speaking with a coworker who was prescribed Adderall several years ago and how he was able to continue his education due to his ability effectively concentrate.  After reading more about the symptoms associated with ADD it seemed to be a perfect match to my condition. This medication has reduced much of my public speaking inhibition; I find that I am more out going, in control, less critical of my self, and more inclined to participate in meeting and activities with minimum anxiety. My sexual drive is actually more enhanced. I am taking 5mg three times daily, but am still adjusting the dosage to alleviate side effects (inability to fall asleep at night) and achieve the maximum benefit. This has been an extremely positive life changing treatment for ADD.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: ive alway knew ive had add, i never seek help for it until i failed out of community college and got accepted into a nursing school. Taking this medication help me a lot! i was actually making a and b, my world was finally coming together. I quit taking it when i found out i was pregnant, i had no withdraw symtoms, the only thing i notice was the add symptoms were back in full affect, it was a long yr and half. I went back on them about a little over yr ago and things are back to normal again. im so glad i finally got treatment, i just wish i would of done it sooner.

column2: frankiedez, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Adderall makes me very sleepy by half way through the day.  So i have to take more.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This drug has been a life saver for me. I am the typical ADD patient. My mind was racing in a hundred directions at once so I wasn't able to focus on anything. Addy helps me slow down and focus my brain enough to acutally complete the tasks I need to and to do it efficiently. Of course, in the beginning, I got a few side effects - dry mouth, appetite loss, diarrhea (dont take with coffee - TRUST ME), and some insomnia. I also found myself craving cigarettes for some odd reason. I found that if I ate a meal before taking it in the morning that it almost eliminated most of them. After a few months your body will get used to it. I DO recommend that if you don't need it on the weekends that you don't take it. That way, your body won't be as likely to get addicted to it. I've been taking it for 4 years and I LOVE IT.

column2: newguy, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have always been successful in life, but at extreme measures (which I thought were normal).  After finding out my older brother had ADHD I started looking into it. What I found was I was a dead on case. So it's been 2 weeks on Adderal and it has made my life easier on every level. Keep in mind it is a stimulant so follow the dose and be true to yourself and talk with your doctor about your reactions on the drug.  Sleep and appetite our at times and issue, but remember to eat frequently and don't take adderall near bed-time. The positives far out weigh anything else. You can actually go thru life and take things as they come.  It doesn't have to feel like you against the world when facing tasks, challenges etc.  A+ for this...

column2: kilacalli, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After trying a few different similar drugs I found that this worked best. With others I lost weight and felt sickly 24/7 (sick to my stomach, weak, lightheaded, dry mouth, just generally terrible). I started taking Adderall, initially in a VERY small dose and I noticed significant improvement. My doctor and I played with the dosage and I'm so happy with the result. The ONLY set back is feeling jittery every now and again. The best solution for that is just to make sure you're eating an appropriate amount. Not tons, but just spread out small meals and snacks and this won't pose a problem. Eating this way is way more healthy anyways. So now I can focus and feel very optimistic about getting things done everyday instead of dreading everything and having no energy, will or attention to finish things (school work). Great drug. I was very nervous to start taking it because I normally refuse all medicine... but this REALLY helped. Just be careful with dosage and eating.

column9: my teen-age daughter has been using it for six years and it turned her academic life around (as well concurrently seeing a significant weight drop). She has had no side effects. From hoping that she would graduate high school to her being a top student in college, it has been amazing.

column2: Savnrse, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: As an adult female who has been taking this drug for years I would warn against it. It works well for me, although it took a long time to find the correct doseage-10mg, but I could NEVER imagine giving this to a child. I am on a low dose and I really feel side effects. Such as tenseness, irratation, lightheadedness, and I just am not myself when I take it. Although the drug does work, I would only recommend it for adults that know their bodies well and know how and when it works for them. It does have sexual side effects as well. For those looking for something for a child, look for something other than these meds, they are NOT for children!

I loath adderall. For whatever reason, it worked for about 6 weeks, and then my moods started getting weird. After taking Adderall for 2 months, I had several severe panic attacks. I never had a panic attack previously. I'd much rather be on ritalin.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years
column9: As an accomplished woman, I didn't know I had ADD until after middle age when increasing I couldn't complete tasks. Depression and loss of self esteem set in but once diagnosed and on medication I was able to slow down, concentrate and finish jobs. column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: It was a wonder for me! I had spent tons of money in medical bills and doctors visits only to realize that what I was battleing with was adult ADHD. This hadn't been as much of a problem for me when I was younger until my job had changed drastically and I lost my ability to focus. Work was terrible and my performance was slipping which made me seem deppressed. Once I started on the medication, it has been like I am a different person. I don't give up on tasks, I complete them, I listen to people when they talk to me,and overall I accomplish the goals I set forth each day. Thank God my doctor finally listened when others did not.
